BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): by Mr. Kin-nosuke Natsume, trans. by Yasotaro Morri
坊っちゃん: 夏目漱石

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Because of an hereditary recklessness, I have been playing always a losing game since my childhood.
坊っちゃん: 親譲（おやゆず）りの無鉄砲（むてっぽう）で小供の時から損ばかりしている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): During my grammar school days, I was once laid up for about a week by jumping from the second story of the school building.
坊っちゃん: 小学校に居る時分学校の二階から飛び降りて一週間ほど腰（こし）を抜（ぬ）かした事がある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Some may ask why I committed such a rash act.
坊っちゃん: なぜそんな無闇（むやみ）をしたと聞く人があるかも知れぬ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): There was no particular reason for doing such a thing
坊っちゃん: 別段深い理由でもない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): except I happened to be looking out into the yard from the second floor of the newly-built school house, when one of my classmates, joking, shouted at me;
坊っちゃん: 新築の二階から首を出していたら、同級生の一人が冗談（じょうだん）に、いくら威張（いば）っても、そこから飛び降りる事は出来まい。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
Say, you big bluff, I'll bet you can't jump down from there!	弱虫やーい。
O, you chicken-heart, ha, ha!
坊っちゃん: と囃（はや）したからである。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): So I jumped down. The janitor of the school had to carry me home on his back, and when my father saw me, he yelled derisively, "What a fellow you are to go and get your bones dislocated by jumping only from a second story!"
坊っちゃん: 小使（こづかい）に負ぶさって帰って来た時、おやじが大きな眼（め）をして二階ぐらいから飛び降りて腰を抜かす奴（やつ）があるかと云（い）ったから、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I'll see I don't get dislocated next time,
坊っちゃん: この次は抜かさずに飛んで見せます

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I answered.
坊っちゃん: と答えた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): One of my relatives once presented me with a pen-knife.
坊っちゃん: 親類のものから西洋製のナイフを貰（もら）って

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I was showing it to my friends, reflecting its pretty blades against the rays of the sun, when one of them chimed in that the blades gleamed all right, but seemed rather dull for cutting with.
坊っちゃん: 奇麗（きれい）な刃（は）を日に翳（かざ）して、友達（ともだち）に見せていたら、一人が光る事は光るが切れそうもないと云った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Rather dull? See if they don't cut! I retorted.
坊っちゃん: 切れぬ事があるか、何でも切ってみせると受け合った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Cut your finger, then, he challenged.
坊っちゃん: そんなら君の指を切ってみろと注文したから、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): And with "Finger nothing! Here goes!" I cut my thumb slant-wise.
坊っちゃん: 何だ指ぐらいこの通りだと右の手の親指の甲（こう）をはすに切り込（こ）んだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Fortunately the knife was small and the bone of the thumb hard enough, so the thumb is still there,
坊っちゃん: 幸（さいわい）ナイフが小さいのと、親指の骨が堅（かた）かったので、今だに親指は手に付いている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): but the scar will be there until my death.
坊っちゃん: しかし創痕（きずあと）は死ぬまで消えぬ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): About twenty steps to the east edge of our garden, there was a moderate-sized vegetable yard, rising toward the south, and in the centre of which stood a chestnut tree
坊っちゃん: 庭を東へ二十歩に行き尽（つく）すと、南上がりにいささかばかりの菜園があって、真中（まんなか）に栗（くり）の木が一本立っている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): which was dearer to me than life.
坊っちゃん: これは命より大事な栗だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): In the season when the chestnuts were ripe, I used to slip out of the house from the back door early in the morning to pick up the chestnuts which had fallen during the night, and eat them at the school.
坊っちゃん: 実の熟する時分は起き抜けに背戸（せど）を出て落ちた奴を拾ってきて、学校で食う。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): On the west side of the vegetable yard was the adjoining garden of a pawn shop called Yamashiro-ya.
坊っちゃん: 菜園の西側が山城屋（やましろや）という質屋の庭続きで、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This shopkeeper's son was a boy about 13 or 14 years old named Kantaro.
坊っちゃん: この質屋に勘太郎（かんたろう）という十三四の倅（せがれ）が居た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Kantaro was, it happens, a mollycoddle.
坊っちゃん: 勘太郎は無論弱虫である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Nevertheless he had the temerity to come over the fence to our yard and steal my chestnuts.
坊っちゃん: 弱虫の癖（くせ）に四つ目垣を乗りこえて、栗を盗（ぬす）みにくる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): One certain evening I hid myself behind a folding-gate of the fence and caught him in the act.
坊っちゃん: ある日の夕方折戸（おりど）の蔭（かげ）に隠（かく）れて、とうとう勘太郎を捕（つら）まえてやった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Having his retreat cut off he grappled with me in desperation.
坊っちゃん: その時勘太郎は逃（に）げ路（みち）を失って、一生懸命（いっしょうけんめい）に飛びかかってきた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He was about two years older than I,
坊っちゃん: 向（むこ）うは二つばかり年上である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and, though weak-kneed, was physically the stronger.
坊っちゃん: 弱虫だが力は強い。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): While I wallopped him, he pushed his head against my breast and by chance it slipped inside my sleeve.
坊っちゃん: 鉢（はち）の開いた頭を、こっちの胸へ宛（あ）ててぐいぐい押（お）した拍子（ひょうし）に、勘太郎の頭がすべって、おれの袷（あわせ）の袖（そで）の中にはいった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): As this hindered the free action of my arm, I tried to shake him loose, though, his head dangled the further inside,
坊っちゃん: 邪魔（じゃま）になって手が使えぬから、無暗に手を振（ふ）ったら、袖の中にある勘太郎の頭が、右左へぐらぐら靡（なび）いた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and being no longer able to stand the stifling combat, he bit my bare arm.
坊っちゃん: しまいに苦しがって袖の中から、おれの二の腕（うで）へ食い付いた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It was painful.
坊っちゃん: 痛かったから

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I held him fast against the fence, and by a dexterous foot twist sent him down flat on his back.
坊っちゃん: 勘太郎を垣根へ押しつけておいて、足搦（あしがら）をかけて向うへ倒（たお）してやった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Kantaro broke the fence and as the ground belonging to Yamashiro-ya was about six feet lower than the vegetable yard, he fell headlong to his own territory with a thud.
坊っちゃん: 山城屋の地面は菜園より六尺がた低い。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): As he rolled off he tore away the sleeve in which his head had been enwrapped, and my arm recovered a sudden freedom of movement.
坊っちゃん: 勘太郎が落ちるときに、おれの袷の片袖がもげて、急に手が自由になった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): That night when my mother went to Yamashiro-ya to apologize, she brought back that sleeve.
坊っちゃん: その晩母が山城屋に詫（わ）びに行ったついでに袷の片袖も取り返して来た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Besides the above, I did many other mischiefs.
坊っちゃん: この外いたずらは大分やった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): With Kaneko of a carpenter shop and Kaku of a fishmarket, I once ruined a carrot patch of one Mosaku.
坊っちゃん: 大工の兼公（かねこう）と肴屋（さかなや）の角（かく）をつれて、茂作（もさく）の人参畠（にんじんばたけ）をあらした事がある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The sprouts were just shooting out and the patch was covered with straws to ensure their even healthy growth.
坊っちゃん: 人参の芽が出揃（でそろ）わぬ処（ところ）へ藁（わら）が一面に敷（し）いてあったから、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Upon this straw-covered patch, we three wrestled for fully half a day, and consequently thoroughly smashed all the sprouts.
坊っちゃん: その上で三人が半日相撲（すもう）をとりつづけに取ったら、人参がみんな踏（ふ）みつぶされてしまった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Also I once filled up a well which watered some rice fields owned by one Furukawa, and he followed me with kicks.
坊っちゃん: 古川（ふるかわ）の持っている田圃（たんぼ）の井戸（いど）を埋（う）めて尻（しり）を持ち込まれた事もある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The well was so devised that from a large bamboo pole, sunk deep into the ground, the water issued and irrigated the rice fields.
坊っちゃん: 太い孟宗（もうそう）の節を抜いて、深く埋めた中から水が湧（わ）き出て、そこいらの稲（いね）にみずがかかる仕掛（しかけ）であった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Ignorant of the mechanical side of this irrigating method at that time, I stuffed the bamboo pole with stones and sticks, and satisfied that no more water came up, I returned home and was eating supper when Furukawa, fiery red with anger, burst into our house with howling protests.
坊っちゃん: その時分はどんな仕掛か知らぬから、石や棒（ぼう）ちぎれをぎゅうぎゅう井戸の中へ挿（さ）し込んで、水が出なくなったのを見届けて、うちへ帰って飯を食っていたら、古川が真赤（まっか）になって怒鳴（どな）り込んで来た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I believe the affair was settled on our paying for the damage.
坊っちゃん: たしか罰金（ばっきん）を出して済んだようである。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Father did not like me in the least,
坊っちゃん: おやじはちっともおれを可愛（かわい）がってくれなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and mother always sided with my big brother.
坊っちゃん: 母は兄ばかり贔屓（ひいき）にしていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This brother's face was palish white, and he had a fondness for taking the part of an actress at the theatre.
坊っちゃん: この兄はやに色が白くって、芝居（しばい）の真似（まね）をして女形（おんながた）になるのが好きだった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This fellow will never amount to much, father used to remark when he saw me.
坊っちゃん: おれを見る度にこいつはどうせ碌（ろく）なものにはならないと、おやじが云った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He's so reckless that I worry about his future,  I often heard mother say of me.
坊っちゃん: 乱暴で乱暴で行く先が案じられると母が云った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Exactly; I have never amounted to much.
坊っちゃん: なるほど碌なものにはならない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I am just as you see me;
坊っちゃん: ご覧の通りの始末である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): no wonder my future used to cause anxiety to my mother.
坊っちゃん: 行く先が案じられたのも無理はない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I am living without becoming but a jailbird.
坊っちゃん: ただ懲役（ちょうえき）に行かないで生きているばかりである。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Two or three days previous to my mother's death, I took it into my head to turn a somersault in the kitchen, and painfully hit my ribs against the corner of the stove.
坊っちゃん: 母が病気で死ぬ二三日（にさんち）前台所で宙返りをしてへっついの角で肋骨（あばらぼね）を撲（う）って大いに痛かった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Mother was very angry at this and told me not to show my face again, so I went to a relative to stay with.
坊っちゃん: 母が大層怒（おこ）って、お前のようなものの顔は見たくないと云うから、親類へ泊（とま）りに行っていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): While there, I received the news that my mother's illness had become very serious, and that after all efforts for her recovery, she was dead.
坊っちゃん: するととうとう死んだと云う報知（しらせ）が来た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I came home thinking that I should have behaved better if I had known the conditions were so serious as that.
坊っちゃん: そう早く死ぬとは思わなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Then that big brother of mine denounced me as wanting in filial piety, and that I had caused her untimely death.
坊っちゃん: そうしたら例の兄がおれを親不孝だ、おれのために、おっかさんが早く死んだんだと云った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Mortified at this, I slapped his face, and thereupon received a sound scolding from father.
坊っちゃん: 口惜（くや）しかったから、兄の横っ面を張って大変叱（しか）られた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): After the death of mother, I lived with father and brother.
坊っちゃん: 母が死んでからは、おやじと兄と三人で暮（くら）していた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Father did nothing, and always said "You're no good" to my face.
坊っちゃん: おやじは何にもせぬ男で、人の顔さえ見れば貴様は駄目（だめ）だ駄目だと口癖のように云っていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): What he meant by "no good" I am yet to understand.
坊っちゃん: 何が駄目なんだか今に分らない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): A funny dad he was.
坊っちゃん: 妙（みょう）なおやじがあったもんだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): My brother was to be seen studying English hard, saying that he was going to be a businessman.
坊っちゃん: 兄は実業家になるとか云ってしきりに英語を勉強していた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He was like a girl by nature, and so "sassy" that we two were never on good terms,
坊っちゃん: 元来女のような性分で、ずるいから、仲がよくなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and had to fight it out about once every ten days.
坊っちゃん: 十日に一遍（いっぺん）ぐらいの割で喧嘩（けんか）をしていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When we played a chess game one day, he placed a chessman as a "waiter,"--a cowardly tactic this,--and had hearty laugh on me by seeing me in a fix.
坊っちゃん: ある時将棋（しょうぎ）をさしたら卑怯（ひきょう）な待駒（まちごま）をして、人が困ると嬉（うれ）しそうに冷やかした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): His manner was so trying that time that I banged a chessman on his forehead
坊っちゃん: あんまり腹が立ったから、手に在った飛車を眉間（みけん）へ擲（たた）きつけてやった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): which was injured a little bit and bled.
坊っちゃん: 眉間が割れて少々血が出た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He told all about this to father,
坊っちゃん: 兄がおやじに言付（いつ）けた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): who said he would disinherit me.
坊っちゃん: おやじがおれを勘当（かんどう）すると言い出した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Then I gave up myself for lost, and expected to be really disinherited.
坊っちゃん: その時はもう仕方がないと観念して先方の云う通り勘当されるつもりでいたら、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But our maid Kiyo, who had been with us for ten years or so, interceded on my behalf, and tearfully apologized for me, and by her appeal my father's wrath was softened.
坊っちゃん: 十年来召し使っている清（きよ）という下女が、泣きながらおやじに詫（あや）まって、ようやくおやじの怒（いか）りが解けた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I did not regard him, however, as one to be afraid of in any way,
坊っちゃん: それにもかかわらずあまりおやじを怖（こわ）いとは思わなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): but rather felt sorry for our Kiyo.
坊っちゃん: かえってこの清と云う下女に気の毒であった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had heard that Kiyo was of a decent, well-to-do family, but being driven to poverty at the time of the Restoration, had to work as a servant.
坊っちゃん: この下女はもと由緒（ゆいしょ）のあるものだったそうだが、瓦解（がかい）のときに零落（れいらく）して、つい奉公（ほうこう）までするようになったのだと聞いている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): So she was an old woman by this time.
坊っちゃん: だから婆（ばあ）さんである。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This old woman,--by what affinity, as the Buddhists say, I don't know,--loved me a great deal.
坊っちゃん: この婆さんがどういう因縁（いんえん）か、おれを非常に可愛がってくれた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Strange, indeed!
坊っちゃん: 不思議なものである。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): She was almost blindly fond of me,--me, whom mother, became thoroughly disgusted with three days before her death;
坊っちゃん: 母も死ぬ三日前に愛想（あいそ）をつかした

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): whom father considered a most aggravating proposition all the year round, and whom the neighbors cordially hated as the local bully among the youngsters.
坊っちゃん: ――おやじも年中持て余している

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had long reconciled myself to the fact that my nature was far from being attractive to others, and so didn't mind if I were treated as a piece of wood;
坊っちゃん: おれは到底（とうてい）人に好かれる性（たち）でないとあきらめていたから、他人から木の端（はし）のように取り扱（あつか）われるのは何とも思わない、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): so I thought it uncommon that Kiyo should pet me like that.
坊っちゃん: かえってこの清のようにちやほやしてくれるのを不審（ふしん）に考えた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Sometimes in the kitchen, when there was nobody around, she would praise me saying that I was straightforward and of a good disposition.
坊っちゃん: 清は時々台所で人の居ない時に

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): What she meant by that exactly, was not clear to me, however.
坊っちゃん: しかしおれには清の云う意味が分からなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If I were of so good a nature as she said, I imagined those other than Kiyo should accord me a better treatment.
坊っちゃん: 好（い）い気性なら清以外のものも、もう少し善くしてくれるだろうと思った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): So whenever Kiyo said to me anything of the kind, I used to answer that I did not like passing compliments.
坊っちゃん: 清がこんな事を云う度におれはお世辞は嫌（きら）いだと答えるのが常であった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Then she would remark; "That's the very reason I say you are of a good disposition,"
坊っちゃん: すると婆さんはそれだから好いご気性ですと云っては、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and would gaze at me with absorbing tenderness.
坊っちゃん: 嬉しそうにおれの顔を眺（なが）めている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): She seemed to recreate me by her own imagination, and was proud of the fact.
坊っちゃん: 自分の力でおれを製造して誇（ほこ）ってるように見える。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I felt even chilled through my marrow at her constant attention to me.
坊っちゃん: 少々気味がわるかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): After my mother was dead, Kiyo loved me still more.
坊っちゃん: 母が死んでから清はいよいよおれを可愛がった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): In my simple reasoning, I wondered why she had taken such a fancy to me.
坊っちゃん: 時々は小供心になぜあんなに可愛がるのかと不審に思った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Sometimes I thought it quite futile on her part, that she had better quit that sort of thing,
坊っちゃん: つまらない、廃（よ）せばいいのにと思った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): which was bad for her.
坊っちゃん: 気の毒だと思った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But she loved me just the same.
坊っちゃん: それでも清は可愛がる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Once in, a while she would buy, out of her own pocket, some cakes or sweetmeats for me.
坊っちゃん: 折々は自分の小遣（こづか）いで金鍔（きんつば）や紅梅焼（こうばいやき）を買ってくれる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When the night was cold, she would secretly buy some noodle powder, and bring all unawares hot noodle gruel to my bed;
坊っちゃん: 寒い夜などはひそかに蕎麦粉（そばこ）を仕入れておいて、いつの間にか寝（ね）ている枕元（まくらもと）へ蕎麦湯を持って来てくれる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): or sometimes she would even buy a bowl of steaming noodles from the peddler.
坊っちゃん: 時には鍋焼饂飩（なべやきうどん）さえ買ってくれた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Not only with edibles,
坊っちゃん: ただ食い物ばかりではない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): but she was generous alike with socks,
坊っちゃん: 靴足袋（くつたび）ももらった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): pencils, note books, etc.
坊っちゃん: 鉛筆（えんぴつ）も貰った、帳面も貰った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): And she even furnished me,--this happened some time later,--with about three yen,
坊っちゃん: これはずっと後の事であるが金を三円ばかり貸してくれた事さえある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I did not ask her for the money;
坊っちゃん: 何も貸せと云った訳ではない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): she offered it from her own good will by bringing it to my room, saying that I might be in need of some cash.
坊っちゃん: 向うで部屋へ持って来てお小遣いがなくてお困りでしょう、お使いなさいと云ってくれたんだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This, of course, embarrassed me, but as she was so insistent I consented to borrow it.
坊っちゃん: おれは無論入らないと云ったが、是非使えと云うから、借りておいた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I confess I was really glad of the money.
坊っちゃん: 実は大変嬉しかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I put it in a bag, and carried it in my pocket.
坊っちゃん: その三円を蝦蟇口（がまぐち）へ入れて、懐（ふところ）へ入れたなり

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): While about the house, I happened to drop the bag into a cesspool.
坊っちゃん: 便所へ行ったら、すぽりと後架（こうか）の中へ落（おと）してしまった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Helpless, I told Kiyo how I had lost the money, and at once she fetched a bamboo stick, and said she will get it for me.
坊っちゃん: 仕方がないから、のそのそ出てきて実はこれこれだと清に話したところが、清は早速竹の棒を捜（さが）して来て、取って上げますと云った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): After a while I heard a splashing sound of water about our family well, and going there, saw Kiyo washing the bag strung on the end of the stick.
坊っちゃん: しばらくすると井戸端（いどばた）でざあざあ音がするから、出てみたら竹の先へ蝦蟇口の紐（ひも）を引き懸（か）けたのを水で洗っていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I opened the bag and found the edict of the three one-yen bills turned to faint yellow and designs fading.
坊っちゃん: それから口をあけて壱円札（いちえんさつ）を改めたら茶色になって模様が消えかかっていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Kiyo dried them at an open fire and handed them over to me, asking if they were all right.
坊っちゃん: 清は火鉢で乾（かわ）かして、これでいいでしょうと出した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I smelled them and said; "They stink yet."
坊っちゃん: ちょっとかいでみて臭（くさ）いやと云ったら、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
Give them to me;	それじゃお出しなさい、
I'll get them changed.
坊っちゃん: 取り換（か）えて来て上げますからと、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): She took those three bills, and,--I do not know how she went about it,--brought three yen in silver.
坊っちゃん: どこでどう胡魔化（ごまか）したか札の代りに銀貨を三円持って来た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I forget now upon what I spent the three yen.
坊っちゃん: この三円は何に使ったか忘れてしまった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I'll pay you back soon, I said at the time, but didn't.
坊っちゃん: 今に返すよと云ったぎり、返さない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I could not now pay it back even if I wished to do so with ten times the amount.
坊っちゃん: 今となっては十倍にして返してやりたくても返せない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When Kiyo gave me anything she did so always when both father and brother were out.
坊っちゃん: 清が物をくれる時には必ずおやじも兄も居ない時に限る。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Many things I do not like, but what I most detest is the monopolizing of favors behind some one else's back.
坊っちゃん: おれは何が嫌いだと云って人に隠れて自分だけ得をするほど嫌いな事はない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Bad as my relations were with my brother, still I did not feel justified in accepting candies or color-pencils from Kiyo without my brother's knowledge.
坊っちゃん: 兄とは無論仲がよくないけれども、兄に隠して清から菓子（かし）や色鉛筆を貰いたくはない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Why do you give those things only to me and not to my brother also? I asked her once,
坊っちゃん: なぜ、おれ一人にくれて、兄さんには遣（や）らないのかと清に聞く事がある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and she answered quite unconcernedly that my brother may be left to himself as his father bought him everything.
坊っちゃん: すると清は澄（すま）したものでお兄様（あにいさま）はお父様（とうさま）が買ってお上げなさるから構いませんと云う。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): That was partiality;
坊っちゃん: これは不公平である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): father was obstinate, but I am sure he was not a man who would indulge in favoritism.
坊っちゃん: おやじは頑固（がんこ）だけれども、そんな依怙贔負（えこひいき）はせぬ男だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): To Kiyo, however, he might have looked that way.
坊っちゃん: しかし清の眼から見るとそう見えるのだろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): There is no doubt that Kiyo was blind to the extent of her undue indulgence with me.
坊っちゃん: 全く愛に溺（おぼ）れていたに違（ちが）いない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): She was said to have come from a well-to-do family, but the poor soul was uneducated, and it could not be helped.
坊っちゃん: 元は身分のあるものでも教育のない婆さんだから仕方がない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): All the same,
坊っちゃん: 単にこればかりではない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): you cannot tell how prejudice will drive one to the extremes.
坊っちゃん: 贔負目は恐ろしいものだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Kiyo seemed quite sure that some day I would achieve high position in society and become famous.
坊っちゃん: 清はおれをもって将来立身出世して立派なものになると思い込んでいた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Equally she was sure that my brother, who was spending his hours studiously, was only good for his white skin, and would stand no show in the future.
坊っちゃん: その癖勉強をする兄は色ばかり白くって、とても役には立たないと一人できめてしまった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Nothing can beat an old woman for this sort of thing, I tell you.
坊っちゃん: こんな婆さんに逢（あ）っては叶（かな）わない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): She firmly believed that whoever she liked would become famous, while whoever she hated would not.
坊っちゃん: 自分の好きなものは必ずえらい人物になって、嫌いなひとはきっと落ち振れるものと信じている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I did not have at that time any particular object in my life.
坊っちゃん: おれはその時から別段何になると云う了見（りょうけん）もなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But the persistency with which Kiyo declared that I would be a great man some day, made me speculate myself that after all I might become one.
坊っちゃん: しかし清がなるなると云うものだから、やっぱり何かに成れるんだろうと思っていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): How absurd it seems to me now when I recall those days.
坊っちゃん: 今から考えると馬鹿馬鹿（ばかばか）しい。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I asked her once what kind of a man I should be,
坊っちゃん: ある時などは清にどんなものになるだろうと聞いてみた事がある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): but she seemed to have formed no concrete idea as to that;
坊っちゃん: ところが清にも別段の考えもなかったようだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): only she said that I was sure to live in a house with grand entrance hall, and ride in a private rikisha.
坊っちゃん: ただ手車（てぐるま）へ乗って、立派な玄関（げんかん）のある家をこしらえるに相違（そうい）ないと云った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): And Kiyo seemed to have decided for herself to live with me when I became independent and occupy my own house.
坊っちゃん: それから清はおれがうちでも持って独立したら、一所（いっしょ）になる気でいた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Please let me live with you, --she repeatedly asked of me.
坊っちゃん: どうか置いて下さいと何遍も繰（く）り返して頼んだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Feeling somewhat that I should eventually be able to own a house, I answered her "Yes," as far as such an answer went.
坊っちゃん: おれも何だかうちが持てるような気がして、うん置いてやると返事だけはしておいた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This woman, by the way, was strongly imaginative.
坊っちゃん: ところがこの女はなかなか想像の強い女で、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): She questioned me what place I liked,--Kojimachi-ku or Azabu-ku?--and suggested that I should have a swing in our garden, that one room be enough for European style, etc., planning everything to suit her own fancy.
坊っちゃん: あなたはどこがお好き、麹町（こうじまち）ですか麻布（あざぶ）ですか、お庭へぶらんこをおこしらえ遊ばせ、西洋間は一つでたくさんですなどと勝手な計画を独りで並（なら）べていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I did not then care a straw for anything like a house;
坊っちゃん: その時は家なんか欲しくも何ともなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): so neither Japanese nor European style was much of use to me, and I told her to that effect.
坊っちゃん: 西洋館も日本建（にほんだて）も全く不用であったから、そんなものは欲しくないと、いつでも清に答えた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Then she would praise me as uncovetous and clean of heart.
坊っちゃん: すると、あなたは欲がすくなくって、心が奇麗だと云ってまた賞めた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Whatever I said, she had praise for me.
坊っちゃん: 清は何と云っても賞めてくれる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I lived, after the death of mother, in this fashion for five or six years.
坊っちゃん: 母が死んでから五六年の間はこの状態で暮していた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had kicks from father,
坊っちゃん: おやじには叱られる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): had rows with brother,
坊っちゃん: 兄とは喧嘩をする。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and had candies and praise from Kiyo.
坊っちゃん: 清には菓子を貰う、時々賞められる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I cared for nothing more;
坊っちゃん: 別に望みもない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I thought this was enough.
坊っちゃん: これでたくさんだと思っていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I imagined all other boys were leading about the same kind of life.
坊っちゃん: ほかの小供も一概（いちがい）にこんなものだろうと思っていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): As Kiyo frequently told me, however, that I was to be pitied, and was unfortunate, I imagined that that might be so.
坊っちゃん: ただ清が何かにつけて、あなたはお可哀想（かわいそう）だ、不仕合（ふしあわせ）だと無暗に云うものだから、それじゃ可哀想で不仕合せなんだろうと思った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): There was nothing that particularly worried me
坊っちゃん: その外に苦になる事は少しもなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): except that father was too tight with my pocket money, and this was rather hard on me.
坊っちゃん: ただおやじが小遣いをくれないには閉口した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): In January of the 6th year after mother's death, father died of apoplexy.
坊っちゃん: 母が死んでから六年目の正月におやじも卒中で亡くなった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): In April of the same year, I graduated from a middle school,
坊っちゃん: その年の四月におれはある私立の中学校を卒業する。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and two months later, my brother graduated from a business college.
坊っちゃん: 六月に兄は商業学校を卒業した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Soon he obtained a job in the Kyushu branch of a certain firm and had to go there,
坊っちゃん: 兄は何とか会社の九州の支店に口があって行（ゆ）かなければならん。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): while I had to remain in Tokyo and continue my study.
坊っちゃん: おれは東京でまだ学問をしなければならない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He proposed the sale of our house and the realization of our property,
坊っちゃん: 兄は家を売って財産を片付けて任地へ出立（しゅったつ）すると云い出した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): to which I answered "Just as you like it."
坊っちゃん: おれはどうでもするがよかろうと返事をした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had no intention of depending upon him anyway.
坊っちゃん: どうせ兄の厄介（やっかい）になる気はない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Even were he to look after me, I was sure of his starting something which would eventually end in a smash-up as we were prone to quarrel on the least pretext.
坊っちゃん: 世話をしてくれるにしたところで、喧嘩をするから、向うでも何とか云い出すに極（きま）っている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It was because in order to receive his protection that I should have to bow before such a fellow,
坊っちゃん: なまじい保護を受ければこそ、こんな兄に頭を下げなければならない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): that I resolved that I would live by myself even if I had to do milk delivery.
坊っちゃん: 牛乳配達をしても食ってられると覚悟（かくご）をした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Shortly afterwards he sent for a second-hand dealer and sold for a song all the bric-a-bric which had been handed down from ages ago in our family.
坊っちゃん: 兄はそれから道具屋を呼んで来て、先祖代々の瓦落多（がらくた）を二束三文（にそくさんもん）に売った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Our house and lot were sold, through the efforts of a middleman to a wealthy person.
坊っちゃん: 家屋敷（いえやしき）はある人の周旋（しゅうせん）である金満家に譲った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This transaction seemed to have netted a goodly sum to him, but I know nothing as to the detail.
坊っちゃん: この方は大分金になったようだが、詳（くわ）しい事は一向知らぬ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): For one month previous to this, I had been rooming in a boarding house in Kanda-ku, pending a decision as to my future course.
坊っちゃん: おれは一ヶ月以前から、しばらく前途の方向のつくまで神田の小川町（おがわまち）へ下宿していた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Kiyo was greatly grieved to see the house in which she had lived so many years change ownership, but she was helpless in the matter.
坊っちゃん: 清は十何年居たうちが人手に渡（わた）るのを大いに残念がったが、自分のものでないから、仕様がなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If you were a little older, you might have inherited this house, she once remarked in earnest.
坊っちゃん: あなたがもう少し年をとっていらっしゃれば、ここがご相続が出来ますものをとしきりに口説いていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If I could have inherited the house through being a little older, I ought to have been able to inherit the house right then.
坊っちゃん: もう少し年をとって相続が出来るものなら、今でも相続が出来るはずだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): She knew nothing, and believed the lack of age only prevented my coming into the possession of the house.
坊っちゃん: 婆さんは何（なんに）も知らないから年さえ取れば兄の家がもらえると信じている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Thus I parted from my brother, but the disposal of Kiyo was a difficult proposition.
坊っちゃん: 兄とおれはかように分れたが、困ったのは清の行く先である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): My brother was, of course, unable to take her along, nor was there any danger of her following him so far away as Kyushu, while I was in a small room of a boarding house, and might have to clear out anytime at that.
坊っちゃん: 兄は無論連れて行ける身分でなし、清も兄の尻にくっ付いて九州下（くんだ）りまで出掛ける気は毛頭なし、と云ってこの時のおれは四畳半（よじょうはん）の安下宿に籠（こも）って、それすらもいざとなれば直ちに引き払（はら）わねばならぬ始末だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): There was no way out,
坊っちゃん: どうする事も出来ん。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): so I asked her
坊っちゃん: 清に聞いてみた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): if she intended to work somewhere else.
坊っちゃん: どこかへ奉公でもする気かねと云ったら

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Finally she answered me definitely that she would go to her nephew's and wait until I started my own house and get married.
坊っちゃん: あなたがおうちを持って、奥（おく）さまをお貰いになるまでは、仕方がないから、甥（おい）の厄介になりましょうとようやく決心した返事をした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This nephew was a clerk in the Court of Justice, and being fairly well off, had invited Kiyo before more than once to come and live with him, but Kiyo preferred to stay with us, even as a servant, since she had become well used to our family.
坊っちゃん: この甥は裁判所の書記でまず今日には差支（さしつか）えなく暮していたから、今までも清に来るなら来いと二三度勧めたのだが、清はたとい下女奉公はしても年来住み馴（な）れた家（うち）の方がいいと云って応じなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But now I think she thought it better to go over to her nephew than to start a new life as servant in a strange house.
坊っちゃん: しかし今の場合知らぬ屋敷へ奉公易（ほうこうが）えをして入らぬ気兼（きがね）を仕直すより、甥の厄介になる方がましだと思ったのだろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Be that as it may, she advised me to have my own household soon, or get married, so she would come and help me in housekeeping.
坊っちゃん: それにしても早くうちを持ての、妻（さい）を貰えの、来て世話をするのと云う。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I believe she liked me more than she did her own kin.
坊っちゃん: 親身（しんみ）の甥よりも他人のおれの方が好きなのだろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): My brother came to me, two days previous to his departure for Kyushu, and giving me 600 yen, said that I might begin a business with it, or go ahead with my study, or spend it in any way I liked, but that that would be the last he could spare.
坊っちゃん: 九州へ立つ二日前兄が下宿へ来て金を六百円出してこれを資本にして商買（しょうばい）をするなり、学資にして勉強をするなり、どうでも随意（ずいい）に使うがいい、その代りあとは構わないと云った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It was a commendable act for my brother.
坊っちゃん: 兄にしては感心なやり方だ、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): What! about only 600 yen! I could get along without it, I thought, but as this unusually simple manner appealed to me, I accepted the offer with thanks.
坊っちゃん: 何の六百円ぐらい貰わんでも困りはせんと思ったが、例に似ぬ淡泊（たんばく）な処置が気に入ったから、礼を云って貰っておいた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Then he produced 50 yen, requesting me to give it to Kiyo next time I saw her, which I readily complied with.
坊っちゃん: 兄はそれから五十円出してこれをついでに清に渡してくれと云ったから、異議なく引き受けた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Two days after, I saw him off at the Shimbashi Station, and have not set my eyes on him ever since.
坊っちゃん: 二日立って新橋の停車場（ていしゃば）で分れたぎり兄にはその後一遍も逢わない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Lying in my bed, I meditated on the best way to spend that 600 yen.
坊っちゃん: おれは六百円の使用法について寝ながら考えた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): A business is fraught with too much trouble, and besides it was not my calling.
坊っちゃん: 商買をしたって面倒（めんど）くさくって旨（うま）く出来るものじゃなし、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Moreover with only 600 yen no one could open a business worth the name.
坊っちゃん: ことに六百円の金で商買らしい商買がやれる訳でもなかろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Were I even able to do it, I was far from being educated, and after all, would lose it.
坊っちゃん: よしやれるとしても、今のようじゃ人の前へ出て教育を受けたと威張れないからつまり損になるばかりだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Better let investments alone, but study more with the money.
坊っちゃん: 資本などはどうでもいいから、これを学資にして勉強してやろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Dividing the 600 yen into three, and by spending 200 yen a year, I could study for three years.
坊っちゃん: 六百円を三に割って一年に二百円ずつ使えば三年間は勉強が出来る。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If I kept at one study with bull-dog tenacity for three years, I should be able to learn something.
坊っちゃん: 三年間一生懸命にやれば何か出来る。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Then the selection of a school was the next problem.
坊っちゃん: それからどこの学校へはいろうと考えたが、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): By nature, there is no branch of study whatever which appeals to my taste.
坊っちゃん: 学問は生来（しょうらい）どれもこれも好きでない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Nix on languages or literature!
坊っちゃん: ことに語学とか文学とか云うものは真平（まっぴら）ご免（めん）だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The new poetry was all Greek to me; I could not make out one single line of twenty.
坊っちゃん: 新体詩などと来ては二十行あるうちで一行も分らない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Since I detested every kind of study, any kind of study should have been the same to me.
坊っちゃん: どうせ嫌いなものなら何をやっても同じ事だと思ったが、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Thinking thus, I happened to pass front of a school of physics, and seeing a sign posted for the admittance of more students, I thought this might be a kind of "affinity," and having asked for the prospectus, at once filed my application for entrance.

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): For three years I studied about as diligently as ordinary fellows, but not being of a particularly brilliant quality, my standing in the class was easier to find by looking up from the bottom.

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had to laugh at myself, but there being no reason for complaint, I passed out.
坊っちゃん: 自分でも可笑（おか）しいと思ったが苦情を云う訳もないから大人しく卒業しておいた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Eight days after my graduation, the principal of the school asked me to come over and see him.
坊っちゃん: 卒業してから八日目に校長が呼びに来たから、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I wondered what he wanted, and went.
坊っちゃん: 何か用だろうと思って、出掛けて行ったら、

坊っちゃん: 四国辺のある中学校で数学の教師が入る。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): for forty yen a month, and he sounded me to see if I would take it.
坊っちゃん: 月給は四十円だが、行ってはどうだという相談である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had studied for three years, but to tell the truth, I had no intention of either teaching or going to the country.
坊っちゃん: おれは三年間学問はしたが実を云うと教師になる気も、田舎（いなか）へ行く考えも何もなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Having nothing in sight, however, except teaching, I readily accepted the offer.
坊っちゃん: もっとも教師以外に何をしようと云うあてもなかったから、この相談を受けた時、行きましょうと即席（そくせき）に返事をした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This too was a blunder due to hereditary recklessness.
坊っちゃん: これも親譲りの無鉄砲が祟（たた）ったのである。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I accepted the position, and so must go there.
坊っちゃん: 引き受けた以上は赴任（ふにん）せねばならぬ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The three years of my school life I had seen confined in a small room,
坊っちゃん: この三年間は四畳半に蟄居（ちっきょ）して小言はただの一度も聞いた事がない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): but with no kick coming or having no rough house.
坊っちゃん: 喧嘩もせずに済んだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It was a comparatively easy going period in my life.
坊っちゃん: おれの生涯のうちでは比較的呑気（ひかくてきのんき）な時節であった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But now I had to pack up.
坊っちゃん: しかしこうなると四畳半も引き払わなければならん。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Once I went to Kamakura on a picnic with my classmates while I was in the grammar school, and that was the first and last, so far, that I stepped outside of Tokyo since I could remember.
坊っちゃん: 生れてから東京以外に踏み出したのは、同級生と一所に鎌倉（かまくら）へ遠足した時ばかりである。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This time I must go darn far away, that it beats Kamakura by a mile.
坊っちゃん: 今度は鎌倉どころではない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The prospective town is situated on the coast, and looked the size of a needle-point on the map.
坊っちゃん: 地図で見ると海浜で針の先ほど小さく見える。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It would not be much to look at anyway.
坊っちゃん: どうせ碌な所ではあるまい。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I knew nothing about the place or the people there.
坊っちゃん: どんな町で、どんな人が住んでるか分らん。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It did not worry me
坊っちゃん: 分らんでも困らない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): or cause any anxiety.
坊っちゃん: 心配にはならぬ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had simply to travel there
坊っちゃん: ただ行くばかりである。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and that was the annoying part.
坊っちゃん: もっとも少々面倒臭い。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Once in a while, since our house was no more, I went to Kiyo's nephew's to see her.
坊っちゃん: 家を畳（たた）んでからも清の所へは折々行った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Her nephew was unusually good-natured,
坊っちゃん: 清の甥というのは存外結構な人である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and whenever I called upon her, he treated me well if he happened to be at home.
坊っちゃん: おれが行（ゆ）くたびに、居（お）りさえすれば、何くれと款待（もて）なしてくれた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Kiyo would boost me sky-high to her nephew right to my face.
坊っちゃん: 清はおれを前へ置いて、いろいろおれの自慢（じまん）を甥に聞かせた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): She went so far once as to say that when I had graduated from school, I would purchase a house somewhere in Kojimachi-ku and get a position in a government office.
坊っちゃん: 今に学校を卒業すると麹町辺へ屋敷を買って役所へ通うのだなどと吹聴（ふいちょう）した事もある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): She decided everything in her own way, and talked of it aloud, and I was made an unwilling and bashful listener.
坊っちゃん: 独りで極（き）めて一人（ひとり）で喋舌（しゃべ）るから、こっちは困（こ）まって顔を赤くした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I do not know how her nephew weighed her tales of self-indulgence on me.
坊っちゃん: それも一度や二度ではない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Kiyo was a woman of the old type, and seemed, as if it was still the days of Feudal Lords,
坊っちゃん: ただ清は昔風（むかしふう）の女だから、自分とおれの関係を封建（ほうけん）時代の主従（しゅじゅう）のように考えていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): to regard her nephew equally under obligation to me even as she was herself.
坊っちゃん: 自分の主人なら甥のためにも主人に相違ないと合点（がてん）したものらしい。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): After settling about my new position, I called upon her three days previous to my departure.
坊っちゃん: いよいよ約束が極まって、もう立つと云う三日前に清を尋（たず）ねたら、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): She was sick abed in a small room,
坊っちゃん: 北向きの三畳に風邪（かぜ）を引いて寝ていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): but, on seeing me she got up and immediately inquired; "Master Darling, when do you begin housekeeping?"
坊っちゃん: おれの来たのを見て起き直るが早いか、坊（ぼ）っちゃんいつ家（うち）をお持ちなさいますと聞いた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): She evidently thought as soon as a fellow finishes school, money comes to his pocket by itself.
坊っちゃん: 卒業さえすれば金が自然とポッケットの中に湧いて来ると思っている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But then how absurd to call such a "great man" "Darling."
坊っちゃん: そんなにえらい人をつらまえて、まだ坊っちゃんと呼ぶのはいよいよ馬鹿気ている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I told her simply that I should let the house proposition go for some time,
坊っちゃん: おれは単簡に当分うちは持たない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): as I had to go to the country.
坊っちゃん: 田舎へ行くんだと云ったら、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): She looked greatly disappointed, and blankly smoothed her gray-haired sidelocks.
坊っちゃん: 非常に失望した容子（ようす）で、胡麻塩（ごましお）の鬢（びん）の乱れをしきりに撫（な）でた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I felt sorry for her,
坊っちゃん: あまり気の毒だから

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and said comfortingly;
坊っちゃん: 「行（ゆ）く事は行くがじき帰る。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
I am going away but will come back soon.	来年の夏休みにはきっと帰る」
I'll return in the vacation next summer, sure.
坊っちゃん: と慰（なぐさ）めてやった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Still as she appeared not fully satisfied,
坊っちゃん: それでも妙な顔をしているから

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I added;
坊っちゃん: 「何を見やげに買って来てやろう、何が欲しい」

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
Will bring you back a surprise.	と聞いてみたら
She wished to eat sasa-ame"[1] of Echigo province.
坊っちゃん: 「越後（えちご）の笹飴（ささあめ）が食べたい」

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had never heard of "sasa-ame" of Echigo.
坊っちゃん: 越後の笹飴なんて聞いた事もない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): To begin with, the location is entirely different.
坊っちゃん: 第一方角が違う。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): There seems to be no 'sasa-ame' in the country where I'm going,
坊っちゃん: 「おれの行く田舎には笹飴はなさそうだ」

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I explained,
坊っちゃん: と云って聞かしたら

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and she rejoined;
坊っちゃん: 「そんなら、どっちの見当です」

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Then, in what direction?
坊っちゃん: と聞き返した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I answered
坊っちゃん: 「西の方だよ」

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): westward
坊っちゃん: と云うと

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and she came back with
坊っちゃん: 「箱根（はこね）のさきですか手前ですか」

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Is it on the other side of Hakone?
坊っちゃん: と問う。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This give-and-take conversation proved too much for me.
坊っちゃん: 随分持てあました。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): On the day of my departure, she came to my room early in the morning and helped me to pack up.
坊っちゃん: 出立の日には朝から来て、いろいろ世話をやいた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): She put into my carpet-bag tooth powder, tooth-brush and towels which she said she had bought at a dry goods store on her way.
坊っちゃん: 来る途中（とちゅう）小間物屋で買って来た歯磨（はみがき）と楊子（ようじ）と手拭（てぬぐい）をズックの革鞄（かばん）に入れてくれた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I protested that I did not want them, but she was insistent.
坊っちゃん: そんな物は入らないと云ってもなかなか承知しない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): [A] We rode in rikishas to the station.
坊っちゃん: 車を並べて停車場へ着いて、

坊っちゃん: プラットフォームの上へ出た時、車へ乗り込んだおれの顔をじっと見て

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and said in a low voice;
坊っちゃん: 「もうお別れになるかも知れません。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
This may be our last good-by.	随分ご機嫌（きげん）よう」
Take care of yourself.

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Her eyes were full of tears.

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I did not cry,
坊っちゃん: おれは泣かなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): but was almost going to.
坊っちゃん: しかしもう少しで泣くところであった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): After the train had run some distance, thinking it would be all right now, I poked my head out of the window and looked back.
坊っちゃん: 汽車がよっぽど動き出してから、もう大丈夫（だいしょうぶ）だろうと思って、窓から首を出して、振り向いたら、

坊っちゃん: ぶうと云（い）って汽船がとまると、艀（はしけ）が岸を離（はな）れて、漕（こ）ぎ寄せて来た。

坊っちゃん: 船頭は真（ま）っ裸（ぱだか）に赤ふんどしをしめている。

坊っちゃん: 野蛮（やばん）な所だ。

坊っちゃん: もっともこの熱さでは着物はきられまい。

坊っちゃん: 日が強いので水がやに光る。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): in such strange colors as to dazzle one's sight if gazed at it for long.
坊っちゃん: 見つめていても眼（め）がくらむ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had been told by a clerk of the ship that I was to get off here.
坊っちゃん: 事務員に聞いてみるとおれはここへ降りるのだそうだ。

坊っちゃん: 人を馬鹿（ばか）にしていらあ、こんな所に我慢（がまん）が出来るものかと思ったが仕方がない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): So, down I jumped first into the boat,
坊っちゃん: 威勢（いせい）よく一番に飛び込んだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and I think five or six others followed me.
坊っちゃん: 続（つ）づいて五六人は乗ったろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): After loading about four large boxes besides, the red-cloth rowed us ashore.
坊っちゃん: 外に大きな箱（はこ）を四つばかり積み込んで赤ふんは岸へ漕ぎ戻（もど）して来た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When the boat struck the sand, I was again the first to jump out, and right away I accosted a skinny urchin standing nearby, asking him where the middle school was.
坊っちゃん: 陸（おか）へ着いた時も、いの一番に飛び上がって、いきなり、磯（いそ）に立っていた鼻たれ小僧（こぞう）をつらまえて中学校はどこだと聞いた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The kid answered blankly that he did not know.
坊っちゃん: 小僧はぼんやりして、知らんがの、と云った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Confound the dull-head!
坊っちゃん: 気の利かぬ田舎（いなか）ものだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Not to know where the middle school was, living in such a tiny bit of a town.
坊っちゃん: 猫（ねこ）の額ほどな町内の癖（くせ）に、中学校のありかも知らぬ奴（やつ）があるものか。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Then a man wearing a rig with short, queer shaped sleeves approached me and bade me follow.
坊っちゃん: ところへ妙（みょう）な筒（つつ）っぽうを着た男がきて、こっちへ来いと云うから、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I walked after him and was taken to an inn called Minato-ya.
坊っちゃん: 尾（つ）いて行ったら、港屋とか云う宿屋へ連れて来た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The maids of the inn, who gave me a disagreeable impression, chorused at sight of me; "Please step inside."
坊っちゃん: やな女が声を揃（そろ）えてお上がりなさいと云うので、

坊っちゃん: 門口へ立ったなり中学校を教えろと云ったら、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): On being told that the middle school was about four miles away by rail, I became still more discouraged at putting up there.
坊っちゃん: 中学校はこれから汽車で二里ばかり行かなくっちゃいけないと聞いて、なお上がるのがいやになった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I snatched my two valises from the man with queer-shaped [B] sleeves who had guided me so far, and strode away.
坊っちゃん: おれは、筒っぽうを着た男から、おれの革鞄（かばん）を二つ引きたくって、のそのそあるき出した。

坊っちゃん: 停車場はすぐ知れた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and a ticket bought without any fuss.
坊っちゃん: 切符（きっぷ）も訳なく買った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The train rambled on for about five minutes, and then I had to get off.

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I then hired a rikisha and arrived at the middle school, but school was already over and nobody was there.
坊っちゃん: それから車を傭（やと）って、中学校へ来たら、もう放課後で誰（だれ）も居ない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The teacher on night-duty was out just for a while, said the janitor,

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He did this with much alacrity and led me to a hotel called Yamashiro-ya.
