BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Although the room was hot, the meal was a deal better than the kind I used to have in my boarding house.
坊っちゃん: 部屋は熱（あ）つかったが、飯は下宿のよりも大分旨（うま）かった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): While waiting on me, she questioned me where I was from, and I said, "from Tokyo."
坊っちゃん: 給仕をしながら下女がどちらからおいでになりましたと聞くから、東京から来たと答えた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Then she asked; "Isn't Tokyo a nice place?" and I shot back, "Bet 'tis."
坊っちゃん: すると東京はよい所でございましょうと云ったから当（あた）り前だと答えてやった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): About the time the maid had reached the kitchen, loud laughs were heard.
坊っちゃん: 膳を下げた下女が台所へいった時分、大きな笑い声が聞（きこ）えた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): There was nothing doing, so I went to bed, but could not sleep.
坊っちゃん: くだらないから、すぐ寝（ね）たが、なかなか寝られない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Not only was it hot,
坊っちゃん: 熱いばかりではない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): but noisy,
坊っちゃん: 騒々（そうぞう）しい。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): --about five times noisier than my boarding house.
坊っちゃん: 下宿の五倍ぐらいやかましい。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): While snoozing, I dreamed of Kiyo.
坊っちゃん: うとうとしたら清（きよ）の夢（ゆめ）を見た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): She was eating "sasa-ame" of Echigo province without taking off the wrapper of bamboo leaves.
坊っちゃん: 清が越後（えちご）の笹飴（ささあめ）を笹ぐるみ、むしゃむしゃ食っている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I tried to stop her, saying bamboo leaves may do her harm, but she replied, "O, no, these leaves are very helpful for the health," and ate them with much relish.
坊っちゃん: 笹は毒だからよしたらよかろうと云うと、いえこの笹がお薬でございますと云（い）って旨そうに食っている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Astounded, I laughed "Ha, ha, ha!" --and so awoke.
坊っちゃん: おれがあきれ返って大きな口を開いてハハハハと笑ったら眼が覚めた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The maid was opening the outside shutters.
坊っちゃん: 下女が雨戸を明けている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The weather was just as clear as the previous day.
坊っちゃん: 相変らず空の底が突（つ）き抜（ぬ）けたような天気だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had heard once before that when travelling, one should give "tea money" to the hotel or inn where he stops;
坊っちゃん: 道中（どうちゅう）をしたら茶代をやるものだと聞いていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): that unless this "tea money" is given, the hostelry would accord him rather rough treatment.
坊っちゃん: 茶代をやらないと粗末（そまつ）に取り扱われると聞いていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It must have been on account of my being slow in the fork over of this "tea money" that they had huddled me into such a narrow, dark room.
坊っちゃん: こんな、狭（せま）くて暗い部屋へ押（お）し込めるのも茶代をやらないせいだろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Likewise my shabby clothes and the carpet bags and satin umbrella must have been accountable for it.
坊っちゃん: 見すぼらしい服装（なり）をして、ズックの革鞄と毛繻子（けじゅす）の蝙蝠傘（こうもり）を提げてるからだろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Took me for a piker, eh? those hayseeds!
坊っちゃん: 田舎者の癖に人を見括（みくび）ったな。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I would give them a knocker with "tea money."
坊っちゃん: 一番茶代をやって驚（おどろ）かしてやろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I left Tokyo with about 30 yen in my pocket, which remained from my school expenses.
坊っちゃん: おれはこれでも学資のあまりを三十円ほど懐（ふところ）に入れて東京を出て来たのだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Taking off the railway and steamship fare, and other incidental expenses, I had still about 14 yen in my pocket.
坊っちゃん: 汽車と汽船の切符代と雑費を差し引いて、まだ十四円ほどある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I could give them all I had;
坊っちゃん: みんなやったって

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): --what did I care, I was going to get a salary now.
坊っちゃん: これからは月給を貰（もら）うんだから構わない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): All country folk are tight-wads, and one 5-yen bill would hit them square.
坊っちゃん: 田舎者はしみったれだから五円もやれば驚（おど）ろいて眼を廻（まわ）すに極（きま）っている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Now watch and see.
坊っちゃん: どうするか見ろと済（すま）して

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Having washed myself, I returned to my room and waited, and the maid of the night before brought in my breakfast.
坊っちゃん: 顔を洗って、部屋へ帰って待ってると、夕べの下女が膳を持って来た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Waiting on me with a tray, she looked at me with a sort of sulphuric smile.
坊っちゃん: 盆（ぼん）を持って給仕をしながら、やににやにや笑ってる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Rude!
坊っちゃん: 失敬な奴だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Is any parade marching on my face? I should say.
坊っちゃん: 顔のなかをお祭りでも通りゃしまいし。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Even my face is far better than that of the maid.
坊っちゃん: これでもこの下女の面（つら）よりよっぽど上等だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I intended of giving "tea money" after breakfast, but I became disgusted, and taking out one 5-yen bill told her to take it to the office later.
坊っちゃん: 飯を済ましてからにしようと思っていたが、癪（しゃく）に障（さわ）ったから、中途（ちゅうと）で五円札（さつ）を一枚（まい）出して、あとでこれを帳場へ持って行けと云ったら、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The face of the maid became then shy and awkward.
坊っちゃん: 下女は変な顔をしていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): After the meal, I left for the school.
坊っちゃん: それから飯を済ましてすぐ学校へ出懸（でか）けた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The maid did not have my shoes polished.
坊っちゃん: 靴（くつ）は磨（みが）いてなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had had vague idea of the direction of the school as I rode to it the previous day,
坊っちゃん: 学校は昨日（きのう）車で乗りつけたから、大概（たいがい）の見当は分っている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): so turning two or three corners, I came to the front gate.
坊っちゃん: 四つ角を二三度曲がったらすぐ門の前へ出た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): From the gate to the entrance the walk was paved with granite.
坊っちゃん: 門から玄関（げんかん）までは御影石（みかげいし）で敷（し）きつめてある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When I had passed to the entrance in the rikisha, this walk made so outlandishly a loud noise that I had felt coy.
坊っちゃん: きのうこの敷石の上を車でがらがらと通った時は、無暗（むやみ）に仰山（ぎょうさん）な音がするので少し弱った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): On my way to the school, I met a number of the students in uniforms of cotton drill and they all entered this gate.
坊っちゃん: 途中から小倉（こくら）の制服を着た生徒にたくさん逢（あ）ったが、みんなこの門をはいって行く。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Some of them were taller than I and looked much stronger.
坊っちゃん: 中にはおれより背が高くって強そうなのが居る。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When I thought of teaching fellows of this ilk, I was impressed with a queer sort of uneasiness.
坊っちゃん: あんな奴を教えるのかと思ったら何だか気味が悪（わ）るくなった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): My card was taken to the principal, to whose room I was ushered at once.
坊っちゃん: 名刺（めいし）を出したら校長室へ通した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): With scant mustache, dark-skinned and big-eyed, the principal was a man who looked like a badger.
坊っちゃん: 校長は薄髯（うすひげ）のある、色の黒い、目の大きな狸（たぬき）のような男である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He studiously assumed an air of superiority,
坊っちゃん: やにもったいぶっていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and saying he would like to see me do my best, handed the note of appointment, stamped big, in a solemn manner.
坊っちゃん: まあ精出して勉強してくれと云って、恭（うやうや）しく大きな印の捺（おさ）った、辞令を渡（わた）した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This note I threw away into the sea on my way back to Tokyo.
坊っちゃん: この辞令は東京へ帰るとき丸めて海の中へ抛り込（こ）んでしまった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He said he would introduce me to all my fellow teachers, and I was to show to each one of them the note of appointment.
坊っちゃん: 校長は今に職員に紹介（しょうかい）してやるから、一々その人にこの辞令を見せるんだと云って聞かした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): What a bother!
坊っちゃん: 余計な手数だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It would be far better to stick this note up in the teachers' room for three days instead of going through such a monkey process.
坊っちゃん: そんな面倒（めんどう）な事をするよりこの辞令を三日間職員室へ張り付ける方がましだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The teachers would not be all in the room until the bugle for the first hour was sounded.
坊っちゃん: 教員が控所（ひかえじょ）へ揃（そろ）うには一時間目の喇叭（らっぱ）が鳴らなくてはならぬ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): There was plenty of time.
坊っちゃん: 大分時間がある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The principal took out his watch, and saying that he would acquaint me particularly with the school by-and-bye, he would only furnish me now with general matters, and started a long lecture on the spirit of education.
坊っちゃん: 校長は時計を出して見て、追々（おいおい）ゆるりと話すつもりだが、まず大体の事を呑（の）み込んでおいてもらおうと云って、それから教育の精神について長いお談義を聞かした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): For a while I listened to him with my mind half away somewhere else, but about half way through his lecture, I began to realize that I should soon be in a bad fix.
坊っちゃん: おれは無論いい加減に聞いていたが、途中からこれは飛んだ所へ来たと思った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I could not do, by any means, all he expected of me.
坊っちゃん: 校長の云うようにはとても出来ない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He expected that I should make myself an example to the students, should become an object of admiration for the whole school or should exert my moral influence, besides teaching technical knowledge in order to become a real educator, or something ridiculously high-sounding.
坊っちゃん: おれみたような無鉄砲（むてっぽう）なものをつらまえて、生徒の模範（もはん）になれの、一校の師表（しひょう）と仰（あお）がれなくてはいかんの、学問以外に個人の徳化を及（およ）ぼさなくては教育者になれないの、と無暗に法外な注文をする。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): No man with such admirable qualities would come so far away for only 40 yen a month!
坊っちゃん: そんなえらい人が月給四十円で遥々（はるばる）こんな田舎へくるもんか。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Men are generally alike.
坊っちゃん: 人間は大概似たもんだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If one gets excited, one is liable to fight, I thought, but if things are to be kept on in the way the principal says, I could hardly open my mouth to utter anything, nor take a stroll around the place.
坊っちゃん: 腹が立てば喧嘩（けんか）の一つぐらいは誰でもするだろうと思ってたが、この様子じゃめったに口も聞けない、散歩も出来ない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If they wanted me to fill such an onerous post, they should have told all that before.
坊っちゃん: そんなむずかしい役なら雇（やと）う前にこれこれだと話すがいい。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I hate to tell a lie;
坊っちゃん: おれは嘘（うそ）をつくのが嫌（きら）いだから、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I would give it up as having been cheated, and get out of this mess like a man there and then.
坊っちゃん: 仕方がない、だまされて来たのだとあきらめて、思い切りよく、ここで断（こと）わって帰っちまおうと思った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had only about 9 yen left in my pocket after tipping the hotel 5 yen.
坊っちゃん: 宿屋へ五円やったから財布（さいふ）の中には九円なにがししかない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Nine yen would not take me back to Tokyo.
坊っちゃん: 九円じゃ東京までは帰れない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had better not have tipped the hotel;
坊っちゃん: 茶代なんかやらなければよかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): what a pity!
坊っちゃん: 惜（お）しい事をした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): However, I would be able to manage it somehow.
坊っちゃん: しかし九円だって、どうかならない事はない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I considered it better to run short in my return expenses than to tell a lie.
坊っちゃん: 旅費は足りなくっても嘘をつくよりましだと思って、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
I cannot do it the way you want me to.	到底（とうてい）あなたのおっしゃる通りにゃ、出来ません、
I return this appointment. I shoved back the note. The principal winked his badger-like eyes and gazed at me.
坊っちゃん: この辞令は返しますと云ったら、校長は狸のような眼をぱちつかせておれの顔を見ていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Then he said; "What I have said just now is what I desire of you. I know well that you cannot do all I want, So don't worry." And he laughed.
坊っちゃん: やがて、今のはただ希望である、あなたが希望通り出来ないのはよく知っているから心配しなくってもいいと云いながら笑った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If he knew it so well already, what on earth did he scare me for?
坊っちゃん: そのくらいよく知ってるなら、始めから威嚇（おどさ）さなければいいのに。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Meanwhile the bugle sounded,
坊っちゃん: そう、こうする内に喇叭が鳴った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): being followed by bustling noises in the direction of the class rooms.
坊っちゃん: 教場の方が急にがやがやする。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): All the teachers would be now ready, I was told, and I followed the principal to the teachers' room.
坊っちゃん: もう教員も控所へ揃いましたろうと云うから、校長に尾いて教員控所へはいった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): In a spacious rectangular room, they sat each before a table lined along the walls.
坊っちゃん: 広い細長い部屋の周囲に机を並（なら）べてみんな腰（こし）をかけている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When I entered the room, they all glanced at me as if by previous agreement.
坊っちゃん: おれがはいったのを見て、みんな申し合せたようにおれの顔を見た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Did they think my face was for a show?
坊っちゃん: 見世物じゃあるまいし。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Then, as per instructions, I introduced myself and showed the note to each one of them.
坊っちゃん: それから申し付けられた通り一人一人（ひとりびとり）の前へ行って辞令を出して挨拶（あいさつ）をした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Most of them left their chairs and made a slight bow of acknowledgment.
坊っちゃん: 大概（たいがい）は椅子（いす）を離れて腰をかがめるばかりであったが、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But some of the more painfully polite took the note and read it and respectfully returned it to me,
坊っちゃん: 念の入ったのは差し出した辞令を受け取って一応拝見をしてそれを恭（うやうや）しく返却（へんきゃく）した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): just like the cheap performances at a rural show!
坊っちゃん: まるで宮芝居の真似（まね）だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When I came to the fifteenth, who was the teacher of physical training, I became impatient at repeating the same old thing so often.
坊っちゃん: 十五人目に体操（たいそう）の教師へと廻って来た時には、同じ事を何返もやるので少々じれったくなった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The other side had to do it only once,
坊っちゃん: 向（むこ）うは一度で済む。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): but my side had to do it fifteen times.
坊っちゃん: こっちは同じ所作（しょさ）を十五返繰り返している。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): They ought to have had some sympathy.
坊っちゃん: 少しはひとの了見（りょうけん）も察してみるがいい。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Among those I met in the room there was Mr. Blank who was head teacher.
坊っちゃん: 挨拶をしたうちに教頭のなにがしと云うのが居た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Said he was a Bachelor of Arts.
坊っちゃん: これは文学士だそうだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I suppose he was a great man since he was a graduate from Imperial University and had such a title.
坊っちゃん: 文学士と云えば大学の卒業生だからえらい人なんだろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He talked in a strangely effeminate voice like a woman.
坊っちゃん: 妙（みょう）に女のような優しい声を出す人だった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But what surprised me most was that he wore a flannel shirt.
坊っちゃん: もっとも驚いたのはこの暑いのにフランネルの襯衣（しゃつ）を着ている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): However thin it might be, flannel is flannel and must have been pretty warm at that time of the year.
坊っちゃん: いくらか薄（うす）い地には相違（そうい）なくっても暑いには極ってる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): What painstaking dress is required which will be becoming to a B.A.!
坊っちゃん: 文学士だけにご苦労千万な服装（なり）をしたもんだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): And it was a red shirt;
坊っちゃん: しかもそれが赤シャツだから

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): wouldn't that kill you!
坊っちゃん: 人を馬鹿（ばか）にしている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I heard afterwards that he wears a red shirt all the year round.
坊っちゃん: あとから聞いたらこの男は年が年中赤シャツを着るんだそうだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): What a strange affliction!
坊っちゃん: 妙な病気があった者だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): According to his own explanation, he has his shirts made to order for the sake of his health as the red color is beneficial to the physical condition.
坊っちゃん: 当人の説明では赤は身体（からだ）に薬になるから、衛生のためにわざわざ誂（あつ）らえるんだそうだが、入らざる心配だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Unnecessary worry, this, for that being the case, he should have had his coat and hakama also in red.
坊っちゃん: そんならついでに着物も袴（はかま）も赤にすればいい。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): And there was one Mr. Koga, teacher of English, whose complexion was very pale.
坊っちゃん: それから英語の教師に古賀（こが）とか云う大変顔色の悪（わ）るい男が居た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Pale-faced people are usually thin, but this man was pale and fat.
坊っちゃん: 大概顔の蒼（あお）い人は瘠（や）せてるもんだがこの男は蒼くふくれている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When I was attending grammar school, there was one Tami Asai in our class, and his father was just as pale as this Koga.
坊っちゃん: 昔（むかし）小学校へ行く時分、浅井（あさい）の民（たみ）さんと云う子が同級生にあったが、この浅井のおやじがやはり、こんな色つやだった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Asai was a farmer, and I asked Kiyo if one's face would become pale if he took up farming.
坊っちゃん: 浅井は百姓（ひゃくしょう）だから、百姓になるとあんな顔になるかと清に聞いてみたら、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Kiyo said it was not so; Asai ate always Hubbard squash of "uranari" [2] and that was the reason.
坊っちゃん: そうじゃありません、あの人はうらなりの唐茄子（とうなす）ばかり食べるから、蒼くふくれるんですと教えてくれた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Thereafter when I saw any man pale and fat, I took it for granted that it was the result of his having eaten too much of squash of "uranari."
坊っちゃん: それ以来蒼くふくれた人を見れば必ずうらなりの唐茄子を食った酬（むく）いだと思う。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This English teacher was surely subsisting upon squash.
坊っちゃん: この英語の教師もうらなりばかり食ってるに違（ちが）いない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): However, what the meaning of "uranari" is, I do not know.
坊っちゃん: もっともうらなりとは何の事か今もって知らない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I asked Kiyo once, but she only laughed.
坊っちゃん: 清に聞いてみた事はあるが、清は笑って答えなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Probably she did not know.
坊っちゃん: 大方清も知らないんだろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Among the teachers of mathematics, there was one named Hotta.
坊っちゃん: それからおれと同じ数学の教師に堀田（ほった）というのが居た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This was a fellow of massive body, with hair closely cropped.
坊っちゃん: これは逞（たくま）しい毬栗坊主（いがぐりぼうず）で、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He looked like one of the old-time devilish priests who made the Eizan temple famous.
坊っちゃん: 叡山（えいざん）の悪僧（あくそう）と云うべき面構（つらがまえ）である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I showed him the note politely, but he did not even look at it, and blurted out; "You're the man newly appointed, eh? Come and see me sometime, ha, ha, ha!"
坊っちゃん: 人が叮寧（ていねい）に辞令を見せたら見向きもせず、やあ君が新任の人か、ちと遊びに来給（きたま）えアハハハと云った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Devil take his "Ha, ha, ha!"
坊っちゃん: 何がアハハハだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Who would go to see a fellow so void of the sense of common decency!
坊っちゃん: そんな礼儀（れいぎ）を心得ぬ奴の所へ誰が遊びに行くものか。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I gave this priest from this time the nickname of Porcupine.
坊っちゃん: おれはこの時からこの坊主に山嵐（やまあらし）という渾名（あだな）をつけてやった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The Confucian teacher was strict in his manneras becoming to his profession.
坊っちゃん: 漢学の先生はさすがに堅（かた）いものだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
Arrived yesterday?	昨日お着きで、
You must be tired.	さぞお疲れで、
Start teaching already?	それでもう授業をお始めで、
Working hard, indeed!
坊っちゃん: 大分ご励精（れいせい）で、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): --and so on.
坊っちゃん: ――とのべつに弁じたのは

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He was an old man, quite sociable and talkative.
坊っちゃん: 愛嬌（あいきょう）のあるお爺（じい）さんだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The teacher of drawing was altogether like a cheap actor.
坊っちゃん: 画学の教師は全く芸人風だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He wore a thin, flappy haori of sukiya, and, toying with a fan, he giggled;
坊っちゃん: べらべらした透綾（すきや）の羽織を着て、扇子（せんす）をぱちつかせて、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
Where from?	お国はどちらでげす、
Tokyo?	東京？
Glad to hear that.	そりゃ嬉（うれ）しい、
You make another of our group.	お仲間が出来て
I'm a Tokyo kid myself.
坊っちゃん: ……私（わたし）もこれで江戸（えど）っ子ですと云った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If such a fellow prided himself on being a Tokyo kid, I wished I had never been born in Tokyo.
坊っちゃん: こんなのが江戸っ子なら江戸には生れたくないもんだと心中に考えた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I might go on writing about each one of them, for there are many,
坊っちゃん: そのほか一人一人についてこんな事を書けばいくらでもある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): but I stop here otherwise there will be no end to it.
坊っちゃん: しかし際限がないからやめる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When my formal introduction was over, the principal said that I might go for the day, but I should make arrangements as to the class hours, etc.,with the head teacher of mathematics and begin teaching from the day after the morrow.
坊っちゃん: 挨拶が一通り済んだら、校長が今日はもう引き取ってもいい、もっとも授業上の事は数学の主任と打ち合せをしておいて、明後日（あさって）から課業を始めてくれと云った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Asked who was the head teacher of mathematics, I found that he was no other than that Porcupine.
坊っちゃん: 数学の主任は誰かと聞いてみたら例の山嵐であった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Holy smokes!
坊っちゃん: 忌々（いまいま）しい、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): was I to serve under him? I was disappointed.
坊っちゃん: こいつの下に働くのかおやおやと失望した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
Say, where are you stopping?	山嵐は
Yamashiro-ya?	「おい君どこに宿（とま）ってるか、山城屋か、うん、今に行って相談する」
Well, I'll come and talk it over.
坊っちゃん: と云い残して白墨（はくぼく）を持って教場へ出て行った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): That was rather humiliating for a head-teacher to come over and see his subordinate,
坊っちゃん: 主任の癖に向うから来て相談するなんて不見識な男だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): but it was better than to call me over to him.
坊っちゃん: しかし呼び付けるよりは感心だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): After leaving the school, I thought of returning straight to the hotel, but as there was nothing to do, I decided to take in a little of the town, and started walking about following my nose.
坊っちゃん: それから学校の門を出て、すぐ宿へ帰ろうと思ったが、帰ったって仕方がないから、少し町を散歩してやろうと思って、無暗に足の向く方をあるき散らした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I saw prefectural building;
坊っちゃん: 県庁も見た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): it was an old structure of the last century.
坊っちゃん: 古い前世紀の建築である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Also I saw the barracks;
坊っちゃん: 兵営も見た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): they were less imposing than those of the Azabu Regiment, Tokyo.
坊っちゃん: 麻布（あざぶ）の聯隊（れんたい）より立派でない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I passed through the main street.
坊っちゃん: 大通りも見た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The width of the street is about one half that of Kagurazaka, and its aspect is inferior.
坊っちゃん: 神楽坂（かぐらざか）を半分に狭くしたぐらいな道幅（みちはば）で町並（まちなみ）はあれより落ちる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): What about a castle-town of 250,000-koku Lord!
坊っちゃん: 二十五万石の城下だって高の知れたものだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Pity the fellows who get swell-headed in such a place as a castle-town!
坊っちゃん: こんな所に住んでご城下だなどと威張（いば）ってる人間は可哀想（かわいそう）なものだ

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): While I walked about musing like this, I found myself in front of Yamashiro-ya.
坊っちゃん: と考えながらくると、いつしか山城屋の前に出た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The town was much narrower than I had been led to believe.
坊っちゃん: 広いようでも狭いものだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
I think I have seen nearly all.	これで大抵（たいてい）は見尽（みつく）したのだろう。
Guess I'll return and eat. And I entered the gate.
坊っちゃん: 帰って飯でも食おうと門口をはいった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The mistress of the hotel who was sitting at the counter, jumped out of her place at my appearance and with "Are you back, Sire!" scraped the floor with her forehead.
坊っちゃん: 帳場に坐（すわ）っていたかみさんが、おれの顔を見ると急に飛び出してきてお帰り……と板の間へ頭をつけた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When I took my shoes off and stepped inside, the maid took me to an upstairs room that had became vacant.
坊っちゃん: 靴（くつ）を脱（ぬ）いで上がると、お座敷（ざしき）があきましたからと下女が二階へ案内をした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It was a front room of 15 mats (about 90 square feet).
坊っちゃん: 十五畳（じょう）の表二階で大きな床（とこ）の間（ま）がついている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had never before lived in so splendid a room as this.
坊っちゃん: おれは生れてからまだこんな立派な座敷へはいった事はない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): As it was quite uncertain when I should again be able to occupy such a room in future, I took off my European dress, and with only a single Japanese summer coat on, sprawled in the centre of the room in the shape of the Japanese letter "big" (arms stretched out and legs spread wide[D]).
坊っちゃん: この後いつはいれるか分らないから、洋服を脱いで浴衣（ゆかた）一枚になって座敷の真中（まんなか）へ大の字に寝てみた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I found it very refreshing.
坊っちゃん: いい心持ちである。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): After luncheon I at once wrote a letter to Kiyo.
坊っちゃん: 昼飯を食ってから早速清へ手紙をかいてやった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I hate most to write letters because I am poor at sentence-making and also poor in my stock of words.
坊っちゃん: おれは文章がまずい上に字を知らないから手紙を書くのが大嫌（だいきら）いだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Neither did I have any place to which to address my letters.
坊っちゃん: またやる所もない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): However, Kiyo might be getting anxious.
坊っちゃん: しかし清は心配しているだろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It would not do to let her worry lest she think the steamer which I boarded had been wrecked and I was drowned,--so I braced up and wrote a long one.
坊っちゃん: 難船して死にやしないかなどと思っちゃ困るから、奮発（ふんぱつ）して長いのを書いてやった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The body of the letter was as follows:
坊っちゃん: その文句はこうである。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
Arrived yesterday.	「きのう着いた。
A dull place.	つまらん所だ。
Am sleeping in a room of 15 mats.	十五畳の座敷に寝ている。
Tipped the hotel five yen as tea money.	宿屋へ茶代を五円やった。
The house-wife of the hotel scraped the floor with her forehead.	かみさんが頭を板の間へすりつけた。
Couldn't sleep last night.	夕べは寝られなかった。
Dreamed Kiyo eat sasa-ame together with the bamboo-leaf wrappers.	清が笹飴を笹ごと食う夢を見た。
Will return next summer.	来年の夏は帰る。
Went to the school to-day, and nicknamed all the fellows.	今日学校へ行ってみんなにあだなをつけてやった。
'Badger' for the principal, 'Red Shirt' for the head-teacher, 'Hubbard Squash' for the teacher of English, 'Porcupine' the teacher of mathematics and 'Clown' for that of drawing.	校長は狸、教頭は赤シャツ、英語の教師はうらなり、数学は山嵐、画学はのだいこ。
Will write you many other things soon.	今にいろいろな事を書いてやる。
Good bye.
坊っちゃん: さようなら」

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When I finished writing the letter, I felt better and sleepy.
坊っちゃん: 手紙をかいてしまったら、いい心持ちになって眠気（ねむけ）がさしたから、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): So I slept in the centre of the room, as I had done before, in the letter "big" shape ([D]).
坊っちゃん: 最前のように座敷の真中へのびのびと大の字に寝た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): No dream this time, and I had a sound sleep.
坊っちゃん: 今度は夢も何も見ないでぐっすり寝た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Is this the room? --a loud voice was heard,--a voice which woke me up, and Porcupine entered.
坊っちゃん: この部屋かいと大きな声がするので目が覚めたら、山嵐がはいって来た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
How do you do?	最前は失敬、
What you have to do in the school----
坊っちゃん: 君の受持ちは……

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): he began talking shop as soon as I got up and rattled me much.
坊っちゃん: と人が起き上がるや否や談判を開かれたので大いに狼狽（ろうばい）した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): On learning my duties in the school, there seemed to be no difficulty, and I decided to accept.
坊っちゃん: 受持ちを聞いてみると別段むずかしい事もなさそうだから承知した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If only such were what was expected of me, I would not be surprised were I told to start not only two days hence but even from the following day.
坊っちゃん: このくらいの事なら、明後日は愚（おろか）、明日（あした）から始めろと云ったって驚ろかない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The talk on business over, Porcupine said that he did not think it was my intention to stay in such a hotel all the time, that he would find a room for me in a good boarding house, and that I should move.
坊っちゃん: 授業上の打ち合せが済んだら、君はいつまでこんな宿屋に居るつもりでもあるまい、僕（ぼく）がいい下宿を周旋（しゅうせん）してやるから移りたまえ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
They wouldn't take in another from anybody else but I can do it right away.	外のものでは承知しないが僕が話せばすぐ出来る。
The sooner the better. Go and look at the room to-day, move tomorrow and start teaching from the next day. That'll be all nice and settled. He seemed satisfied by arranging all by himself.
坊っちゃん: 早い方がいいから、今日見て、あす移って、あさってから学校へ行けば極りがいいと一人で呑み込んでいる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Indeed, I should not be able to occupy such a room for long.
坊っちゃん: なるほど十五畳敷にいつまで居る訳にも行くまい。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I might have to blow in all of my salary for the hotel bill and yet be short of squaring it.
坊っちゃん: 月給をみんな宿料（しゅくりょう）に払（はら）っても追っつかないかもしれぬ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It was pity to leave the hotel so soon after I had just shone with a 5-yen tip.
坊っちゃん: 五円の茶代を奮発（ふんぱつ）してすぐ移るのはちと残念だが、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): However, it being decidedly convenient to move and get settled early if I had to move at all, I asked Porcupine to get that room for me.
坊っちゃん: どうせ移る者なら、早く引き越（こ）して落ち付く方が便利だから、そこのところはよろしく山嵐に頼（たの）む事にした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He told me then to come over with him and see the house at any rate, and I did.
坊っちゃん: すると山嵐はともかくもいっしょに来てみろと云うから、行った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The house was situated mid-way up a hill at the end of the town, and was a quiet.
坊っちゃん: 町はずれの岡の中腹にある家で至極閑静（かんせい）だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The boss was said to be a dealer in antique curios, called Ikagin, and his wife was about four years his senior.
坊っちゃん: 主人は骨董（こっとう）を売買するいか銀と云う男で、女房（にょうぼう）は亭主（ていしゅ）よりも四つばかり年嵩（としかさ）の女だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I learned the English word "witch" when I was in middle school, and this woman looked exactly like one.
坊っちゃん: 中学校に居た時ウィッチと云う言葉を習った事があるがこの女房はまさにウィッチに似ている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But as she was another man's wife, what did I care if she was a witch.
坊っちゃん: ウィッチだって人の女房だから構わない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Finally I decided to live in the house from the next day.
坊っちゃん: とうとう明日から引き移る事にした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): On our way back Porcupine treated me to a cup of ice-water.
坊っちゃん: 帰りに山嵐は通町（とおりちょう）で氷水を一杯奢（ぱいおご）った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When I first met him in the school, I thought him a disgustingly overbearing fellow, but judging by the way he had looked after me so far, he appeared not so bad after all.
坊っちゃん: 学校で逢った時はやに横風（おうふう）な失敬な奴だと思ったが、こんなにいろいろ世話をしてくれるところを見ると、わるい男でもなさそうだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Only he seemed, like me, impatient by nature and of quick-temper.
坊っちゃん: ただおれと同じようにせっかちで肝癪持（かんしゃくもち）らしい。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I heard afterward that he was liked most by all the students in the school.
坊っちゃん: あとで聞いたらこの男が一番生徒に人望があるのだそうだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): My teaching began at last.
坊っちゃん: いよいよ学校へ出た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When I entered the class-room and stepped upon the platform for the first time, I felt somewhat strange.
坊っちゃん: 初めて教場へはいって高い所へ乗った時は、何だか変だった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): While lecturing, I wondered if a fellow like me could keep up the profession of public instructor.
坊っちゃん: 講釈をしながら、おれでも先生が勤まるのかと思った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The students were noisy.
坊っちゃん: 生徒はやかましい。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Once in a while, they would holler "Teacher!" "Teacher," --it was "going some."
坊っちゃん: 時々図抜（ずぬ）けた大きな声で先生と云（い）う。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had been calling others "teacher" every day so far, in the school of physics, but in calling others "teacher" and being called one, there is a wide gap of difference.
坊っちゃん: 先生には応（こた）えた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It made me feel as if some one was tickling my soles.
坊っちゃん: 何だか足の裏がむずむずする。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I am not a sneakish fellow, nor a coward;
坊っちゃん: おれは卑怯（ひきょう）な人間ではない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): only--it's a pity--I lack audacity.
坊っちゃん: 臆病（おくびょう）な男でもないが、惜（お）しい事に胆力（たんりょく）が欠けている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If one calls me "teacher" aloud, it gives me a shock similar to that of hearing the noon-gun in Marunouchi when I was hungry.
坊っちゃん: 先生と大きな声をされると、腹の減った時に丸の内で午砲（どん）を聞いたような気がする。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The first hour passed away in a dashing manner.
坊っちゃん: 最初の一時間は何だかいい加減にやってしまった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): And it passed away without encountering any knotty questions.
坊っちゃん: しかし別段困った質問も掛（か）けられずに済んだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): As I returned to the teachers' room, Porcupine asked me how it was.
坊っちゃん: 控所（ひかえじょ）へ帰って来たら、山嵐がどうだいと聞いた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I simply answered "well," and he seemed satisfied.
坊っちゃん: うんと単簡に返事をしたら山嵐は安心したらしかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When I left the teachers' room, chalk in hand, for the second hour class, I felt as if I was invading the enemy's territory.
坊っちゃん: 二時間目に白墨（はくぼく）を持って控所を出た時には何だか敵地へ乗り込（こ）むような気がした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): On entering the room, I found the students for this hour were all big fellows.
坊っちゃん: 教場へ出ると今度の組は前より大きな奴（やつ）ばかりである。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I am a Tokyo kid, delicately built and small, and did not appear very impressive even in my elevated position.
坊っちゃん: おれは江戸（えど）っ子で華奢（きゃしゃ）に小作りに出来ているから、どうも高い所へ上がっても押（お）しが利かない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If it comes to a scraping, I can hold my own even with wrestlers, but I had no means of appearing awe-inspiring[E], merely by the aid of my tongue, to so many as forty such big chaps before me.
坊っちゃん: 喧嘩（けんか）なら相撲取（すもうとり）とでもやってみせるが、こんな大僧（おおぞう）を四十人も前へ並（なら）べて、ただ一枚（まい）の舌をたたいて恐縮（きょうしゅく）させる手際はない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Believing, however, that it would set a bad precedent to show these country fellows any weakness, I lectured rather loudly and in brusque tone.
坊っちゃん: しかしこんな田舎者（いなかもの）に弱身を見せると癖（くせ）になると思ったから、なるべく大きな声をして、少々巻き舌で講釈してやった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): During the first part the students were taken aback and listened literally with their mouths open.
坊っちゃん: 最初のうちは、生徒も烟（けむ）に捲（ま）かれてぼんやりしていたから、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): That's one on you! I thought. Elated by my success, I kept on in this tone, when one who looked the strongest, sitting in the middle of the front row, stood up suddenly, and called "Teacher!"
坊っちゃん: それ見ろとますます得意になって、べらんめい調を用いてたら、一番前の列の真中（まんなか）に居た、一番強そうな奴が、いきなり起立して先生と云う。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): There it goes!--I thought, and asked him what it was.
坊っちゃん: そら来たと思いながら、何だと聞いたら、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
A-ah sa-ay, you talk too quick.	「あまり早くて分からんけれ、
A-ah ca-an't you make it a leetle slow?	もちっと、ゆるゆる遣（や）って、おくれんかな、
A-ah?
坊っちゃん: もし」

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): A-ah ca-an't you? "A-ah?" was altogether dull.
坊っちゃん: おくれんかな、もしは生温（なまぬ）るい言葉だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
If I talk too fast, I'll make it slow, but I'm a Tokyo fellow, and can't talk the way you do.	早過ぎるなら、ゆっくり云ってやるが、おれは江戸っ子だから君等（きみら）の言葉は使えない、
If you don't understand it, better wait until you do. So I answered him.
坊っちゃん: 分（わか）らなければ、分るまで待ってるがいいと答えてやった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): In this way the second hour was closed better than I had expected.
坊っちゃん: この調子で二時間目は思ったより、うまく行った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Only, as I was about to leave the class, one of the students asked me, "A-ah say, won't you please do them for me?" and showed me some problems in geometry which I was sure I could not solve. This proved to be somewhat a damper on me.
坊っちゃん: ただ帰りがけに生徒の一人がちょっとこの問題を解釈をしておくれんかな、もし、と出来そうもない幾何（きか）の問題を持って逼（せま）ったには冷汗（ひやあせ）を流した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But, helpless, I told him I could not make them out, and telling him that I would show him how next time, hastily got out of the room.
坊っちゃん: 仕方がないから何だか分らない、この次教えてやると急いで引き揚（あ）げたら、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): And all of them raised "Whee--ee!"
坊っちゃん: 生徒がわあと囃（はや）した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Some of them were heard saying "He doesn't know much."
坊っちゃん: その中に出来ん出来んと云う声が聞（きこ）える。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Don't take a teacher for an encyclopaedia!
坊っちゃん: 箆棒（べらぼう）め、先生だって、出来ないのは当り前だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If I could work out such hard questions as these easily, I would not be in such a backwoods town for forty yen a month. I returned to the teachers' room.
坊っちゃん: そんなものが出来るくらいなら四十円でこんな田舎へくるもんかと控所へ帰って来た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): How was it this time? asked Porcupine.
坊っちゃん: 今度はどうだとまた山嵐が聞いた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I said "Umh."
坊っちゃん: うんと云ったが、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But not satisfied with "Umh" only, I added that all the students in this school were boneheads.
坊っちゃん: うんだけでは気が済まなかったから、この学校の生徒は分らずやだなと云ってやった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He put up a whimsical face.
坊っちゃん: 山嵐は妙（みょう）な顔をしていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The third and the fourth hour and the first hour in the afternoon were more or less the same.
坊っちゃん: 三時間目も、四時間目も昼過ぎの一時間も大同小異であった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): In all the classes I attended, I made some kind of blunder.
坊っちゃん: 最初の日に出た級は、いずれも少々ずつ失敗した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I realised that the profession of teaching not quite so easy a calling as might have appeared.
坊っちゃん: 教師ははたで見るほど楽じゃないと思った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): My teaching for the day was finished but I could not get away.
坊っちゃん: 授業はひと通り済んだが、まだ帰れない、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had to wait alone until three o'clock.
坊っちゃん: 三時までぽつ然（ねん）として待ってなくてはならん。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I understood that at three o'clock the students of my classes would finish cleaning up the rooms and report to me, whereupon I would go over the rooms.
坊っちゃん: 三時になると、受持級の生徒が自分の教室を掃除（そうじ）して報知（しらせ）にくるから検分をするんだそうだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Then I would run through the students' roll, and then be free to go home.
坊っちゃん: それから、出席簿（しゅっせきぼ）を一応調べてようやくお暇（ひま）が出る。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Outrageous, indeed, to keep on chained to the school, staring at the empty space when he had nothing more to do, even though he was "bought" by a salary!
坊っちゃん: いくら月給で買われた身体（からだ）だって、あいた時間まで学校へ縛（しば）りつけて机と睨（にら）めっくらをさせるなんて法があるものか。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Other fellow teachers, however, meekly submitted to the regulation, and believing it not well for me,--a new comer--to fuss about it, I stood it.
坊っちゃん: しかしほかの連中はみんな大人（おとな）しくご規則通りやってるから新参のおればかり、だだを捏（こ）ねるのもよろしくないと思って我慢（がまん）していた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): On my way home, I appealed to Porcupine as to the absurdity of keeping me there till three o'clock regardless of my having nothing to do in the school.
坊っちゃん: 帰りがけに、君何でもかんでも三時過（すぎ）まで学校にいさせるのは愚（おろか）だぜと山嵐に訴えたら、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He said "Yes" and laughed.
坊っちゃん: 山嵐はそうさアハハハと笑ったが、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But he became serious and in an advisory manner told me not to make many complaints about the school.
坊っちゃん: あとから真面目（まじめ）になって、君あまり学校の不平を云うと、いかんぜ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
Talk to me only, if you want to.	云うなら僕（ぼく）だけに話せ、
There are some queer guys around.
坊っちゃん: 随分（ずいぶん）妙な人も居るからなと忠告がましい事を云った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): As we parted at the next corner, I did not have time to hear more from him.
坊っちゃん: 四つ角で分れたから詳（くわ）しい事は聞くひまがなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): On reaching my room, the boss of the house came to me saying, "Let me serve you tea."
坊っちゃん: それからうちへ帰ってくると、宿の亭主（ていしゅ）がお茶を入れましょうと云ってやって来る。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I expected he was going to treat me to some good tea since he said "Let me serve you," but he simply made himself at home and drank my own tea.
坊っちゃん: お茶を入れると云うからご馳走（ちそう）をするのかと思うと、おれの茶を遠慮（えんりょ）なく入れて自分が飲むのだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Judging by this, I thought he might be practising "Let me serve you" during my absence.
坊っちゃん: この様子では留守中（るすちゅう）も勝手にお茶を入れましょうを一人（ひとり）で履行（りこう）しているかも知れない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The boss said that he was fond of antique drawings and curios and finally had decided to start in that business.
坊っちゃん: 亭主が云うには手前は書画骨董（しょがこっとう）がすきで、とうとうこんな商買を内々で始めるようになりました。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
You look like one quite taken about art.	あなたもお見受け申すところ大分ご風流でいらっしゃるらしい。
Suppose you begin patronizing my business just for fun as er--connoisseur of art? It was the least expected kind of solicitation.
坊っちゃん: ちと道楽にお始めなすってはいかがですと、飛んでもない勧誘（かんゆう）をやる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Two years ago, I went to the Imperial Hotel (Tokyo) on an errand, and I was taken for a locksmith.
坊っちゃん: 二年前ある人の使（つかい）に帝国（ていこく）ホテルへ行った時は錠前（じょうまえ）直しと間違（まちが）えられた事がある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When I went to see the Daibutsu at Kamakura, haying wrapped up myself from head to toe with a blanket, a rikisha man addressed me as "Gov'ner."
坊っちゃん: ケットを被（かぶ）って、鎌倉（かまくら）の大仏を見物した時は車屋から親方と云われた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I have been mistaken on many occasions for as many things, but none so far has counted on me as a probable connoisseur of art.
坊っちゃん: その外今日（こんにち）まで見損（みそくな）われた事は随分あるが、まだおれをつらまえて大分ご風流でいらっしゃると云ったものはない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): One should know better by my appearance.
坊っちゃん: 大抵（たいてい）はなりや様子でも分る。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Any one who aspires to be a patron of art is usually pictured,--you may see in any drawing,--with either a hood on his head, or carrying a tanzaku[3] in his hand.
坊っちゃん: 風流人なんていうものは、画（え）を見ても、頭巾（ずきん）を被（かぶ）るか短冊（たんざく）を持ってるものだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The fellow who calls me a connoisseur of art and pretends to mean it, may be surely as crooked as a dog's hind legs.
坊っちゃん: このおれを風流人だなどと真面目に云うのはただの曲者（くせもの）じゃない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I told him I did not like such art-stuff, which is usually favored by retired people.
坊っちゃん: おれはそんな呑気（のんき）な隠居（いんきょ）のやるような事は嫌（きら）いだと云ったら、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He laughed, and remarking that that nobody liked it at first, but once in it, will find it so fascinating that he will hardly get over it, served tea for himself and drank it in a grotesque manner.
坊っちゃん: 亭主はへへへへと笑いながら、いえ始めから好きなものは、どなたもございませんが、いったんこの道にはいるとなかなか出られませんと一人で茶を注いで妙な手付（てつき）をして飲んでいる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I may say that I had asked him the night before to buy some tea for me, but I did not like such a bitter, heavy kind.
坊っちゃん: 実はゆうべ茶を買ってくれと頼（たの）んでおいたのだが、こんな苦い濃（こ）い茶はいやだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): One swallow seemed to act right on my stomach.
坊っちゃん: 一杯（ぱい）飲むと胃に答えるような気がする。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I told him to buy a kind not so bitter as that, and he answered "All right, Sir," and drank another cup.
坊っちゃん: 今度からもっと苦くないのを買ってくれと云ったら、かしこまりましたとまた一杯しぼって飲んだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The fellow seemed never to know of having enough of anything so long as it was another man's.
坊っちゃん: 人の茶だと思って無暗（むやみ）に飲む奴（やつ）だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): After he left the room, I prepared for the morrow and went to bed.
坊っちゃん: 主人が引き下がってから、明日の下読（したよみ）をしてすぐ寝（ね）てしまった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Everyday thereafter I attended at the school and worked as per regulations.
坊っちゃん: それから毎日毎日学校へ出ては規則通り働く、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Every day on my return, the boss came to my room with the same old "Let me serve you tea."
坊っちゃん: 毎日毎日帰って来ると主人がお茶を入れましょうと出てくる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): In about a week I understood the school in a general way, and had my own idea as to the personality of the boss and his wife.
坊っちゃん: 一週間ばかりしたら学校の様子もひと通りは飲み込めたし、宿の夫婦の人物も大概（たいがい）は分った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I heard from one of my fellow teachers that the first week to one month after the receipt of the appointment worried them most as to whether they had been favorably received among the students.
坊っちゃん: ほかの教師に聞いてみると辞令を受けて一週間から一ヶ月ぐらいの間は自分の評判がいいだろうか、悪（わ）るいだろうか非常に気に掛（か）かるそうであるが、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I never felt anything on that score.
坊っちゃん: おれは一向そんな感じはなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Blunders in the class room once in a while caused me chagrin, but in about half an hour everything would clear out of my head.
坊っちゃん: 教場で折々しくじるとその時だけはやな心持ちだが三十分ばかり立つと奇麗（きれい）に消えてしまう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I am a fellow who, by nature, can't be worrying long about[F] anything even if I try to.
坊っちゃん: おれは何事によらず長く心配しようと思っても心配が出来ない男だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I was absolutely indifferent as how my blunders in the class room affected the students, or how much further they affected the principal or the head-teacher.
坊っちゃん: 教場のしくじりが生徒にどんな影響（えいきょう）を与（あた）えて、その影響が校長や教頭にどんな反応を呈（てい）するかまるで無頓着（むとんじゃく）であった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): As I mentioned before, I am not a fellow of much audacity to speak of, but I am quick to give up anything when I see its finish.
坊っちゃん: おれは前に云う通りあまり度胸の据（すわ）った男ではないのだが、思い切りはすこぶるいい人間である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had resolved to go elsewhere at once if the school did not suit me.
坊っちゃん: この学校がいけなければすぐどっかへ行（ゆ）く覚悟（かくご）でいたから、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): In consequence, neither Badger nor Red Shirt wielded any influence over me.
坊っちゃん: 狸（たぬき）も赤シャツも、ちっとも恐（おそろ）しくはなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): And still less did I feel like coaxing or coddling the youngsters in the class room.
坊っちゃん: まして教場の小僧（こぞう）共なんかには愛嬌（あいきょう）もお世辞も使う気になれなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): So far it was O.K. with the school, but not so easy as that at my boarding house.
坊っちゃん: 学校はそれでいいのだが下宿の方はそうはいかなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I could have stood it if it had been only the boss coming to my room after my tea.
坊っちゃん: 亭主が茶を飲みに来るだけなら我慢もするが、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But he would fetch many things to my room.
坊っちゃん: いろいろな者を持ってくる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): First time he brought in seals.[4]
坊っちゃん: 始めに持って来たのは何でも印材で、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He displayed about ten of them before me and persuaded me to buy them for three yen, which was very cheap, he said.
坊っちゃん: 十（とお）ばかり並（なら）べておいて、みんなで三円なら安い物だお買いなさいと云う。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Did he take me for a third rate painter making a round of the country?
坊っちゃん: 田舎巡（いなかまわ）りのヘボ絵師じゃあるまいし、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I told him I did not want them.
坊っちゃん: そんなものは入らないと云ったら、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Next time he brought in a panel picture of flowers and birds, drawn by one Kazan or somebody.
坊っちゃん: 今度は華山（かざん）とか何とか云う男の花鳥の掛物（かけもの）をもって来た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He hung it against the wall of the alcove and asked me if it was not well done, and I echoed it looked well done.
坊っちゃん: 自分で床（とこ）の間（ま）へかけて、いい出来じゃありませんかと云うから、そうかなと好加減（いいかげん）に挨拶（あいさつ）をすると、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Then he started lecturing about Kazan, that there are two Kazans, one is Kazan something and the other is Kazan anything, and that this picture was the work of that Kazan something.
坊っちゃん: 華山には二人（ふたり）ある、一人は何とか華山で、一人は何とか華山ですが、この幅（ふく）はその何とか華山の方だと、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): After this nonsensical lecture, he insisted that he would make it fifteen yen for me to buy it.
坊っちゃん: くだらない講釈をしたあとで、どうです、あなたなら十五円にしておきます。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I declined the offer saying that I was shy of the money.
坊っちゃん: 金がないと断わると、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): You can pay any time. He was insistent.
坊っちゃん: 金なんか、いつでもようございますとなかなか頑固（がんこ）だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I settled him by telling him of my having no intention of purchasing it even if I had the necessary money.
坊っちゃん: 金があつても買わないんだと、その時は追っ払（ぱら）っちまった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Again next time, he yanked in a big writing stone slab about the size of a ridge-tile.
坊っちゃん: その次には鬼瓦（おにがわら）ぐらいな大硯（おおすずり）を担ぎ込んだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This is a tankei,[5] he said.
坊っちゃん: これは端渓（たんけい）です、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): As he "tankeied" two or three times, I asked for fun what was a tankei.
坊っちゃん: 端渓ですと二遍（へん）も三遍も端渓がるから、面白半分に端渓た何だいと聞いたら、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Right away he commenced lecturing on the subject.
坊っちゃん: すぐ講釈を始め出した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): There are the upper, the middle and the lower stratum in tankei, he said.
坊っちゃん: 端渓には上層中層下層とあって、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Most of tankei slabs to-day are made from the upper stratum, he continued,
坊っちゃん: 今時のものはみんな上層ですが、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
but this one is surely from the middle stratum.	これはたしかに中層です、
Look at this 'gan.'[6]	この眼（がん）をご覧なさい。
'Tis certainly rare to have three 'gans' like this.	眼が三つあるのは珍（めず）らしい。
The ink-cake grates smoothly on it.	溌墨（はつぼく）の具合も至極よろしい、
Try it, sir,
坊っちゃん: 試してご覧なさいと、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): --and he pushed it towards me.
坊っちゃん: おれの前へ大きな硯を突（つ）きつける。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I asked him how much, and he answered that on account of its owner having brought it from China and wishing to sell if as soon as possible, he would make it very cheap, that I could have it for thirty yen.
坊っちゃん: いくらだと聞くと、持主が支那（しな）から持って帰って来て是非売りたいと云いますから、お安くして三十円にしておきましょうと云う。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I was sure he was a fool.
坊っちゃん: この男は馬鹿（ばか）に相違（そうい）ない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I seemed to be able to get through the school somehow, but I would soon give out if this "curio siege" kept on long.
坊っちゃん: 学校の方はどうかこうか無事に勤まりそうだが、こう骨董責（こっとうぜめ）に逢（あ）ってはとても長く続きそうにない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Shortly afterwards, I began to get sick of the school.
坊っちゃん: そのうち学校もいやになった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): One certain night, while I was strolling about a street named Omachi, I happened to notice a sign of noodles below of which was annotated "Tokyo" in the house next to the post office.
坊っちゃん: ある日の晩大町（おおまち）と云う所を散歩していたら郵便局の隣（とな）りに蕎麦（そば）とかいて、下に東京と注を加えた看板があった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I am very fond of noodles.
坊っちゃん: おれは蕎麦が大好きである。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): While I was in Tokyo, if I passed by a noodle house and smelled the seasoning spices, I felt uncontrollable temptation to go inside at any cost.
坊っちゃん: 東京に居（お）った時でも蕎麦屋の前を通って薬味の香（にお）いをかぐと、どうしても暖簾（のれん）がくぐりたくなった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Up to this time I had forgotten the noodle on account of mathematics and antique curios, but since I had seen thus the sign of noodles, I could hardly pass it by unnoticed.
坊っちゃん: 今日までは数学と骨董で蕎麦を忘れていたが、こうして看板を見ると素通りが出来なくなる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): So availing myself of this opportunity, I went in.
坊っちゃん: ついでだから一杯食って行こうと思って上がり込んだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It was not quite up to what I had judged by the sign.
坊っちゃん: 見ると看板ほどでもない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Since it claimed to follow the Tokyo style, they should have tidied up a little bit about the room.
坊っちゃん: 東京と断（こと）わる以上はもう少し奇麗にしそうなものだが、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): They did not either know Tokyo or have the means,--I did not know which, but the room was miserably dirty.
坊っちゃん: 東京を知らないのか、金がないのか、滅法（めっぽう）きたない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The floor-mats had all seen better days and felt shaggy with sandy dust.
坊っちゃん: 畳（たたみ）は色が変ってお負けに砂でざらざらしている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The sootcovered walls defied the blackest black.
坊っちゃん: 壁（かべ）は煤（すす）で真黒（まっくろ）だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The ceiling was not only smoked by the lamp black, but was so low as to force one involuntarily bend down his neck.
坊っちゃん: 天井（てんじょう）はランプの油烟（ゆえん）で燻（くす）ぼってるのみか、低くって、思わず首を縮めるくらいだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Only the price-list, on which was glaringly written "Noodles" and which was pasted on the wall, was entirely new.
坊っちゃん: ただ麗々と蕎麦の名前をかいて張り付けたねだん付けだけは全く新しい。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I was certain that they bought an old house and opened the business just two or three days before.
坊っちゃん: 何でも古いうちを買って二三日（にさんち）前から開業したに違（ちが）いなかろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): At the head of the price-list appeared "tempura" (noodles served with shrimp fried in batter).
坊っちゃん: ねだん付の第一号に天麩羅（てんぷら）とある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Say, fetch me some tempura, I ordered in a loud voice.
坊っちゃん: おい天麩羅を持ってこいと大きな声を出した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Then three fellows who had been making a chewing noise together in a corner, looked in my direction.
坊っちゃん: するとこの時まで隅（すみ）の方に三人かたまって、何かつるつる、ちゅうちゅう食ってた連中（れんじゅう）が、ひとしくおれの方を見た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): As the room was dark I did not notice them at first. But when we looked at each other, I found them all to be boys in our school.
坊っちゃん: 部屋（へや）が暗いので、ちょっと気がつかなかったが顔を合せると、みんな学校の生徒である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): They "how d'ye do'd" me and I acknowledged it.
坊っちゃん: 先方で挨拶（あいさつ）をしたから、おれも挨拶をした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): That night, having come across the noodle after so long a time, it tasted so fine that I ate four bowls.
坊っちゃん: その晩は久（ひさ）し振（ぶり）に蕎麦を食ったので、旨（うま）かったから天麩羅を四杯平（たいら）げた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The next day as I entered the class room quite unconcernedly, I saw on the black board written in letters so large as to take up the whole space; "Professor Tempura."
坊っちゃん: 翌日何の気もなく教場へはいると、黒板一杯ぐらいな大きな字で、天麩羅先生とかいてある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The boys all glanced at my face and made merry hee-haws at my cost.
坊っちゃん: おれの顔を見てみんなわあと笑った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It was so absurd that I asked them if it was in any way funny for me to eat tempura noodle.
坊っちゃん: おれは馬鹿馬鹿しいから、天麩羅を食っちゃ可笑（おか）しいかと聞いた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Thereupon one of them said, --"But four bowls is too much."
坊っちゃん: すると生徒の一人（ひとり）が、しかし四杯は過ぎるぞな、もし、と云った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): What did they care if I ate four bowls or five as long as I paid it with my own money,--and speedily finishing up my class, I returned to the teachers' room.
坊っちゃん: 四杯食おうが五杯食おうがおれの銭でおれが食うのに文句があるもんかと、さっさと講義を済まして控所へ帰って来た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): After tenminutes' recess, I went to the next class, and there on the black board was newly written quite as large as before;
坊っちゃん: 十分立って次の教場へ出ると一つ天麩羅四杯なり。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Four bowls of tempura noodles, but don't laugh.
坊っちゃん: 但（ただ）し笑うべからず。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The first one did not arouse any ill-temper in me, but this time it made me feel irritating mad.
坊っちゃん: さっきは別に腹も立たなかったが今度は癪（しゃく）に障（さわ）った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): A joke carried too far becomes mischievous.
坊っちゃん: 冗談（じょうだん）も度を過ごせばいたずらだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It is like the undue jealousy of some women who, like coal, look black and suggest flames.
坊っちゃん: 焼餅（やきもち）の黒焦（くろこげ）のようなもので

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Nobody likes it.
坊っちゃん: 誰（だれ）も賞（ほ）め手はない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): These country simpletons, unable to differentiate upon so delicate a boundary, would seem to be bent on pushing everything to the limit.
坊っちゃん: 田舎者はこの呼吸が分からないからどこまで押（お）して行っても構わないと云う了見（りょうけん）だろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): As they lived in such a narrow town where one has no more to see if he goes on strolling about for one hour, and as they were capable of doing nothing better, they were trumpeting aloud this tempura incident in quite as serious a manner as the Russo-Japanese war.
坊っちゃん: 一時間あるくと見物する町もないような狭（せま）い都に住んで、外に何にも芸がないから、天麩羅事件を日露（にちろ）戦争のように触（ふ）れちらかすんだろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): What a bunch of miserable pups!
坊っちゃん: 憐（あわ）れな奴等（やつら）だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It is because they are raised in this fashion from their boyhood that there are many punies who, like the dwarf maple tree in the flower pot, mature gnarled and twisted.
坊っちゃん: 小供の時から、こんなに教育されるから、いやにひねっこびた、植木鉢（うえきばち）の楓（かえで）みたような小人（しょうじん）が出来るんだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I have no objection to laugh myself with others over innocent jokes.
坊っちゃん: 無邪気（むじゃき）ならいっしょに笑ってもいいが、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But how's this?
坊っちゃん: こりゃなんだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Boys as they are, they showed a "poisonous temper."
坊っちゃん: 小供の癖（くせ）に乙（おつ）に毒気を持ってる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Silently erasing off "tempura" from the board, I questioned them if they thought such mischief interesting, that this was a cowardly joke
坊っちゃん: おれはだまって、天麩羅を消して、こんないたずらが面白いか、卑怯（ひきょう）な冗談だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and if they knew the meaning of "cowardice."
坊っちゃん: 君等は卑怯と云う意味を知ってるか、と云ったら、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Some of them answered that to get angry on being laughed at over one's own doing, was cowardice.
坊っちゃん: 自分がした事を笑われて怒（おこ）るのが卑怯じゃろうがな、もしと答えた奴がある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): What made them so disgusting as this?
坊っちゃん: やな奴だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I pitied myself for coming from far off Tokyo to teach such a lot.
坊っちゃん: わざわざ東京から、こんな奴を教えに来たのかと思ったら情なくなった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Keep your mouth shut, and study hard, I snapped, and started the class.
坊っちゃん: 余計な減らず口を利かないで勉強しろと云って、授業を始めてしまった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): In the next class again there was written: "When one eats tempura noodles it makes him drawl nonsense."
坊っちゃん: それから次の教場へ出たら天麩羅を食うと減らず口が利きたくなるものなりと書いてある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): There seemed no end to it.
坊っちゃん: どうも始末に終えない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I was thoroughly aroused with anger, and declaring that I would not teach such sassies, went home straight.
坊っちゃん: あんまり腹が立ったから、そんな生意気な奴は教えないと云ってすたすた帰って来てやった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The boys were glad of having an unexpected holiday, so I heard.
坊っちゃん: 生徒は休みになって喜んだそうだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When things had come to this pass, the antique curious seemed far more preferable to the school.
坊っちゃん: こうなると学校より骨董の方がまだましだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): My return home and sleep over night greatly rounded off my rugged temper over the tempura affair.
坊っちゃん: 天麩羅蕎麦もうちへ帰って、一晩寝たらそんなに肝癪（かんしゃく）に障らなくなった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I went to the school, and they were there also.
坊っちゃん: 学校へ出てみると、生徒も出ている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I could not tell what was what.
坊っちゃん: 何だか訳が分らない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The three days thereafter were pacific, and on the night of the fourth day, I went to a suburb called Sumida and ate "dango" (small balls made of glutinous rice, dressed with sugar-paste).
坊っちゃん: それから三日ばかりは無事であったが、四日目の晩に住田（すみた）と云う所へ行って団子（だんご）を食った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Sumida is a town where there are restaurants, hot-springs bath houses and a park, and in addition, the "tenderloin."
坊っちゃん: この住田と云う所は温泉のある町で城下から汽車だと十分ばかり、歩いて三十分で行かれる、料理屋も温泉宿も、公園もある上に遊廓（ゆうかく）がある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The dango shop where I went was near the entrance to the tenderloin, and as the dango served there was widely known for its nice taste, I dropped in on my way back from my bath.
坊っちゃん: おれのはいった団子屋は遊廓の入口にあって、大変うまいという評判だから、温泉に行った帰りがけにちょっと食ってみた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): As I did not meet any students this time, I thought nobody knew of it, but when I entered the first hour class next day, I found written on the black board; "Two dishes of dango--7 sen."
坊っちゃん: 今度は生徒にも逢わなかったから、誰（だれ）も知るまいと思って、翌日学校へ行って、一時間目の教場へはいると団子二皿（さら）七銭と書いてある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It is true that I ate two dishes and paid seven sen.
坊っちゃん: 実際おれは二皿食って七銭払（はら）った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Troublesome kids! I declare.
坊っちゃん: どうも厄介（やっかい）な奴等だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I expected with certainty that there would be something at the second hour, and there it was; "The dango in the tenderloin taste fine."
坊っちゃん: 二時間目にもきっと何かあると思うと遊廓の団子旨い旨いと書いてある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Stupid wretches!
坊っちゃん: あきれ返った奴等だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): No sooner I thought, the dango incident closed than the red towel became the topic for widespread gossip.
坊っちゃん: 団子がそれで済んだと思ったら今度は赤手拭（あかてぬぐい）と云うのが評判になった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Inquiry as to the story revealed it to be something unusually absurd.
坊っちゃん: 何の事だと思ったら、つまらない来歴だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Since, my arrival here, I had made it a part of my routine to take in the hot springs bath every day.
坊っちゃん: おれはここへ来てから、毎日住田の温泉へ行く事に極（き）めている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): While there was nothing in this town which compared favorably with Tokyo, the hot springs were worthy of praise.
坊っちゃん: ほかの所は何を見ても東京の足元にも及（およ）ばないが温泉だけは立派なものだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): So long as I was in the town, I decided that I would have a dip every day, and went there walking, partly for physical exercise, before my supper.
坊っちゃん: せっかく来た者だから毎日はいってやろうという気で、晩飯前に運動かたがた出掛（でかけ）る。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): And whenever I went there I used to carry a large-size European towel dangling from my hand.
坊っちゃん: ところが行くときは必ず西洋手拭の大きな奴をぶら下げて行く。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Added to somewhat reddish color the towel had acquired by its having been soaked in the hot-springs, the red color on its border, which was not fast enough, streaked about so that the towel now looked as if it were dyed red.
坊っちゃん: この手拭が湯に染（そま）った上へ、赤い縞（しま）が流れ出したのでちょっと見ると紅色（べにいろ）に見える。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This towel hung down from my hand on both ways whether afoot or riding in the train.
坊っちゃん: おれはこの手拭を行きも帰りも、汽車に乗ってもあるいても、常にぶら下げている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): For this reason, the students nicknamed me Red Towel.
坊っちゃん: それで生徒がおれの事を赤手拭赤手拭と云うんだそうだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Honest, it is exasperating to live in a little town.
坊っちゃん: どうも狭い土地に住んでるとうるさいものだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): There is some more.
坊っちゃん: まだある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The bath house I patronized was a newly built three-story house, and for the patrons of the first class the house provided a bath-robe, in addition to an attendant, and the cost was only eight sen.
坊っちゃん: 温泉は三階の新築で上等は浴衣（ゆかた）をかして、流しをつけて八銭で済む。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): On top of that, a maid would serve tea in a regular polite fashion.
坊っちゃん: その上に女が天目（てんもく）へ茶を載（の）せて出す。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I always paid the first class.
坊っちゃん: おれはいつでも上等へはいった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Then those gossipy spotters started saying that for one who made only forty yen a month to take a first class bath every day was extravagant.
坊っちゃん: すると四十円の月給で毎日上等へはいるのは贅沢（ぜいたく）だと云い出した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Why the devil should they care? It was none of their business.
坊っちゃん: 余計なお世話だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): There is still some more.
坊っちゃん: まだある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The bath-tub,--or the tank in this case,--was built of granite, and measured about thirty square feet.
坊っちゃん: 湯壺（ゆつぼ）は花崗石（みかげいし）を畳（たた）み上げて、十五畳敷（じょうじき）ぐらいの広さに仕切ってある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Usually there were thirteen or fourteen people in the tank, but sometimes there was none.
坊っちゃん: 大抵（たいてい）は十三四人漬（つか）ってるがたまには誰も居ない事がある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): As the water came up clear to the breast, I enjoyed, for athletic purposes, swimming in the tank.
坊っちゃん: 深さは立って乳の辺まであるから、運動のために、湯の中を泳ぐのはなかなか愉快（ゆかい）だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I delighted in swimming in this 30-square feet tank, taking chances of the total absence of other people.
坊っちゃん: おれは人の居ないのを見済（みすま）しては十五畳の湯壺を泳ぎ巡（まわ）って喜んでいた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Once, going downstairs from the third story with a light heart, and peeping through the entrance of the tank to see if I should be able to swim, I noticed a sign put up in which was boldly written: "No swimming allowed in the tank."
坊っちゃん: ところがある日三階から威勢（いせい）よく下りて今日も泳げるかなとざくろ口を覗（のぞ）いてみると、大きな札へ黒々と湯の中で泳ぐべからずとかいて貼（は）りつけてある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): As there may not have been many who swam in the tank, this notice was probably put up particularly for my sake.
坊っちゃん: 湯の中で泳ぐものは、あまりあるまいから、この貼札（はりふだ）はおれのために特別に新調したのかも知れない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): After that I gave up swimming.
坊っちゃん: おれはそれから泳ぐのは断念した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But although I gave up swimming, I was surprised, when I went to the school, to see on the board, as usual, written: "No swimming allowed in the tank."
坊っちゃん: 泳ぐのは断念したが、学校へ出てみると、例の通り黒板に湯の中で泳ぐべからずと書いてあるには驚（おど）ろいた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It seemed as if all the students united in tracking me everywhere.
坊っちゃん: 何だか生徒全体がおれ一人を探偵（たんてい）しているように思われた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): They made me sick.
坊っちゃん: くさくさした。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I was not a fellow to stop doing whatever I had started upon no matter what students might say, but I became thoroughly disgusted when I meditated on why I had come to such a narrow, suffocating place.
坊っちゃん: 生徒が何を云ったって、やろうと思った事をやめるようなおれではないが、何でこんな狭苦しい鼻の先がつかえるような所へ来たのかと思うと情なくなった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): And, then, when I returned home, the "antique curio siege" was still going on.
坊っちゃん: それでうちへ帰ると相変らず骨董責である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): For us teachers there was a duty of night watch in the school, and we had to do it in turn.
坊っちゃん: 学校には宿直があって、職員が代る代るこれをつとめる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But Badger and Red Shirt were not in it.
坊っちゃん: 但（ただ）し狸（たぬき）と赤シャツは例外である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): On asking why these two were exempt from this duty, I was told that they were accorded by the government treatment similar to officials of "Sonin" rank.
坊っちゃん: 何でこの両人が当然の義務を免（まぬ）かれるのかと聞いてみたら、奏任待遇（そうにんたいぐう）だからと云う。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Oh, fudge!
坊っちゃん: 面白くもない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): They were paid more, worked less, and were then excused from this night watch.
坊っちゃん: 月給はたくさんとる、時間は少ない、それで宿直を逃（の）がれるなんて

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It was not fair.
坊っちゃん: 不公平があるものか。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): They made regulations to suit their convenience and seemed to regard all this as a matter of course.
坊っちゃん: 勝手な規則をこしらえて、それが当（あた）り前（まえ）だというような顔をしている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): How could they be so brazen faced as this!
坊っちゃん: よくまああんなにずうずうしく出来るものだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I was greatly dissatisfied relative to this question, but according to the opinion of Porcupine, protests by a single person, with what insistency they may be made, will not be heard.
坊っちゃん: これについては大分不平であるが、山嵐（やまあらし）の説によると、いくら一人（ひとり）で不平を並（なら）べたって通るものじゃないそうだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): They ought to be heard whether they are made by one person or by two if they are just.
坊っちゃん: 一人だって二人（ふたり）だって正しい事なら通りそうなものだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Porcupine remonstrated with me by quoting "Might is right" in English.
坊っちゃん: 山嵐は might is right という英語を引いて説諭（せつゆ）を加えたが、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I did not catch his point, so I asked him again, and he told me that it meant the right of the stronger.
坊っちゃん: 何だか要領を得ないから、聞き返してみたら強者の権利と云う意味だそうだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If it was the right of the stronger I had known it for long,
坊っちゃん: 強者の権利ぐらいなら昔（むかし）から知っている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and did not require Porcupine explain that to me at this time.
坊っちゃん: 今さら山嵐から講釈をきかなくってもいい。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The right of the stronger was a question different from that of the night watch.
坊っちゃん: 強者の権利と宿直とは別問題だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Who would agree that Badger and Red Shirt were the stronger?
坊っちゃん: 狸や赤シャツが強者だなんて、誰（だれ）が承知するものか。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): But argument or no argument, the turn of this night watch at last fell upon me.
坊っちゃん: 議論は議論としてこの宿直がいよいよおれの番に廻（まわ）って来た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Being quite fastidious, I never enjoyed sound sleep unless I slept comfortably in my own bedding.
坊っちゃん: 一体疳性（かんしょう）だから夜具蒲団（やぐふとん）などは自分のものへ楽に寝ないと寝たような心持ちがしない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): From my childhood, I never stayed out overnight.
坊っちゃん: 小供の時から、友達のうちへ泊（とま）った事はほとんどないくらいだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When I did not find sleeping under the roof of my friends inviting, night watch in the school, you may be sure, was still worse.
坊っちゃん: 友達のうちでさえ厭（いや）なら学校の宿直はなおさら厭だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): However repulsive, if this was a part of the forty yen a month,
坊っちゃん: 厭だけれども、これが四十円のうちへ籠（こも）っているなら仕方がない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): there was no alternative. I had to do it.
坊っちゃん: 我慢（がまん）して勤めてやろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): To remain alone in the school after the faculty and students had gone home, was something particularly awkward.
坊っちゃん: 教師も生徒も帰ってしまったあとで、一人ぽかんとしているのは随分（ずいぶん）間が抜（ぬ）けたものだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The room for the night watch was in the rear of the school building at the west end of the dormitory.

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I only do not know how because I am honest.
坊っちゃん: 正直だから、どうしていいか分らないんだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Just think,--if the honest does not win, what else is there in this world that will win?
坊っちゃん: 世の中に正直が勝たないで、外に勝つものがあるか、考えてみろ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If I cannot beat them to-night, I will tomorrow;
坊っちゃん: 今夜中に勝てなければ、あした勝つ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): if not tomorrow, then the day after tomorrow.
坊っちゃん: あした勝てなければ、あさって勝つ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If not the day after tomorrow, I will sit down right here, get my meals from my home until I beat them.
坊っちゃん: あさって勝てなければ、下宿から弁当を取り寄せて勝つまでここに居る。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Thus resolved, I squatted in the middle of the corridor and waited for the dawn.
坊っちゃん: おれはこう決心をしたから、廊下の真中へあぐらをかいて夜のあけるのを待っていた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Myriads of mosquitoes swarmed about me, but I did not mind them.
坊っちゃん: 蚊がぶんぶん来たけれども何ともなかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I felt my leg where I hit it a while ago;
坊っちゃん: さっき、ぶつけた向脛を撫（な）でてみると、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): it seemed bespattered with something greasy.
坊っちゃん: 何だかぬらぬらする。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I thought it was bleeding.
坊っちゃん: 血が出るんだろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Let it bleed all it cares!
坊っちゃん: 血なんか出たければ勝手に出るがいい。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Meanwhile, exhausted by these unwonted affairs, I fell asleep.
坊っちゃん: そのうち最前からの疲（つか）れが出て、ついうとうと寝てしまった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): When I awoke, up I jumped with a curse.
坊っちゃん: 何だか騒がしいので、眼（め）が覚めた時はえっ糞（くそ）しまったと飛び上がった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The door on my right was half opened, and two students were standing in front of me.
坊っちゃん: おれの坐（すわ）ってた右側にある戸が半分あいて、生徒が二人、おれの前に立っている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The moment I recovered my senses from the drowsy lull, I grabbed a leg of one of them nearest to me, and yanked it with all my might.
坊っちゃん: おれは正気に返って、はっと思う途端に、おれの鼻の先にある生徒の足を引（ひ）っ攫（つか）んで、力任せにぐいと引いたら、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He fell down prone.
坊っちゃん: そいつは、どたりと仰向（あおむけ）に倒れた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Look at what you're getting now!
坊っちゃん: ざまを見ろ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I flew at the other fellow, who was much confused;
坊っちゃん: 残る一人がちょっと狼狽（ろうばい）したところを、飛びかかって、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): gave him vigorous shaking twice or thrice, and he only kept open his bewildering eyes.
坊っちゃん: 肩を抑（おさ）えて二三度こづき廻したら、あっけに取られて、眼をぱちぱちさせた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Come up to my room.
坊っちゃん: さあおれの部屋まで来い

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Evidently they were mollycoddles, for they obeyed my command without a murmur.
坊っちゃん: と引っ立てると、弱虫だと見えて、一も二もなく尾（つ）いて来た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The day had become already clear.
坊っちゃん: 夜（よ）はとうにあけている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I began questioning those two in my room, but,--you cannot pound out the leopard's spots no matter how you may try,--they seemed determined to push it through by an insistent declaration of "not guilty," that they would not confess.
坊っちゃん: おれが宿直部屋へ連れてきた奴を詰問（きつもん）し始めると、豚は、打（ぶ）っても擲いても豚だから、ただ知らんがなで、どこまでも通す了見と見えて、けっして白状しない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): While this questioning was going on, the students upstairs came down, one by one, and began congregating in my room.
坊っちゃん: そのうち一人来る、二人来る、だんだん二階から宿直部屋へ集まってくる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I noticed all their eyes were swollen from want of sleep.
坊っちゃん: 見るとみんな眠（ねむ）そうに瞼（まぶた）をはらしている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
Blooming nice faces you got for not sleeping only one night.	けちな奴等だ。
And you call yourselves men!	そんな面をして男と云われるか。
Go, wash your face and come back to hear what I've got to tell you. I hurled this shot at them, but none of them went to wash his face.
坊っちゃん: 面でも洗って議論に来いと云ってやったが、誰も面を洗いに行かない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): For about one hour, I had been talking and back-talking with about fifty students when suddenly Badger put in his appearance.
坊っちゃん: おれは五十人あまりを相手に約一時間ばかり押問答（おしもんどう）をしていると、ひょっくり狸がやって来た。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I heard afterward that the janitor ran to Badger for the purpose of reporting to him that there was a trouble in the school.
坊っちゃん: あとから聞いたら、小使が学校に騒動がありますって、わざわざ知らせに行ったのだそうだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): What a weak-knee of the janitor to fetch the principal for so trifling an affair as this!
坊っちゃん: これしきの事に、校長を呼ぶなんて意気地がなさ過ぎる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): No wonder he cannot see better times than a janitor.
坊っちゃん: それだから中学校の小使なんぞをしてるんだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The principal listened to my explanation,
坊っちゃん: 校長はひと通りおれの説明を聞いた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and also to brief remarks from the students.
坊っちゃん: 生徒の言草（いいぐさ）もちょっと聞いた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
Attend school as usual till further notice.	追って処分するまでは、今まで通り学校へ出ろ。
Hurry up with washing your face and breakfast; there isn't much time left.
坊っちゃん: 早く顔を洗って、朝飯を食わないと時間に間に合わないから、早くしろと云って

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): So the principal let go all the students.
坊っちゃん: 寄宿生をみんな放免（ほうめん）した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Decidedly slow way of handling, this.
坊っちゃん: 手温（てぬ）るい事だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If I were the principal, I would expel them right away.
坊っちゃん: おれなら即席（そくせき）に寄宿生をことごとく退校してしまう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It is because the school accords them such luke-warm treatment that they get "fresh" and start "guying" the night watch.
坊っちゃん: こんな悠長（ゆうちょう）な事をするから生徒が宿直員を馬鹿にするんだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He said to me that it must have been trying on my nerves, and that I might be tired, and also that I need not teach that day.
坊っちゃん: その上おれに向って、あなたもさぞご心配でお疲れでしょう、今日はご授業に及（およ）ばんと云うから、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): To this I replied:
坊っちゃん: おれはこう答えた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
No, Sir, no worrying at all.	「いえ、ちっとも心配じゃありません。
Such things may happen every night, but it would not disturb me in the least as long as I breathe.	こんな事が毎晩あっても、命のある間は心配にゃなりません。
I will do the teaching.	授業はやります、
If I were not able to teach on account of lack of sleep for only one single night, I would make a rebate of my salary to the school.
坊っちゃん: 一晩ぐらい寝なくって、授業が出来ないくらいなら、頂戴（ちょうだい）した月給を学校の方へ割戻（わりもど）します」

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I do not know how this impressed him, but he gazed at me for a while, and called my attention to the fact that my face was rather swollen.
坊っちゃん: 校長は何と思ったものか、しばらくおれの顔を見つめていたが、しかし顔が大分はれていますよと注意した。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Indeed, I felt it heavy.
坊っちゃん: なるほど何だか少々重たい気がする。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Besides, it itched all over.
坊っちゃん: その上べた一面痒（かゆ）い。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I was sure the mosquitoes must have stung me there to their hearts' content.
坊っちゃん: 蚊がよっぽと刺（さ）したに相違ない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I further added: "My face may be swollen, but I can talk all right; so I will teach; " thus scratching my face with some warmth.
坊っちゃん: おれは顔中ぼりぼり掻（か）きながら、顔はいくら膨（は）れたって、口はたしかにきけますから、授業には差し支（つか）えませんと答えた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The principal smiled and remarked, "Well, you have the strength."
坊っちゃん: 校長は笑いながら、大分元気ですねと賞（ほ）めた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): To tell the truth, he did not intend remark to be a compliment, but, I think, a sneer.
坊っちゃん: 実を云うと賞めたんじゃあるまい、ひやかしたんだろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Won't you go fishing?
坊っちゃん: 君釣（つ）りに行きませんか

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): asked Red Shirt
坊っちゃん: と赤シャツがおれに聞いた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He talks in a strangely womanish voice.
坊っちゃん: 赤シャツは気味の悪（わ）るいように優しい声を出す男である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): One would not be able to tell whether he was a man or a woman.
坊っちゃん: まるで男だか女だか分（わか）りゃしない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): As a man he should talk like one.
坊っちゃん: 男なら男らしい声を出すもんだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Is he not a college graduate?
坊っちゃん: ことに大学卒業生じゃないか。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I can talk man-like enough, and am a graduate from a school of physics at that.
坊っちゃん: 物理学校でさえおれくらいな声が出るのに、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): It is a shame for a B.A. to have such a squeak.
坊っちゃん: 文学士がこれじゃ見っともない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I answered with the smallest enthusiasm, whereupon he further asked me an impolite question if I ever did fishing.
坊っちゃん: おれはそうですなあと少し進まない返事をしたら、君釣をした事がありますかと失敬な事を聞く。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I told him not much, that I once caught three gibels when I was a boy, at a fishing game pond at Koume,
坊っちゃん: あんまりないが、子供の時、小梅（こうめ）の釣堀（つりぼり）で鮒（ふな）を三匹（びき）釣った事がある。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and that I also caught a carp about eight inches long, at a similar game at the festival of Bishamon at Kagurazaka;
坊っちゃん: それから神楽坂（かぐらざか）の毘沙門（びしゃもん）の縁日（えんにち）で八寸ばかりの鯉（こい）を針で引っかけて、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): --the carp, just as I was coaxing it out of the water, splashed back into it, and when I think of the incident I feel mortified at the loss even now.
坊っちゃん: しめたと思ったら、ぽちゃりと落としてしまったがこれは今考えても惜（お）しいと云（い）ったら、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Red Shirt stuck out his chin and laughed "ho, ho."
坊っちゃん: 赤シャツは顋（あご）を前の方へ突（つ）き出してホホホホと笑った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Why could he not laugh just like an ordinary person?
坊っちゃん: 何もそう気取って笑わなくっても、よさそうな者だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Then you are not well acquainted with the spirit of the game,
坊っちゃん: 「それじゃ、まだ釣りの味は分らんですな。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I'll show you if you like.
坊っちゃん: お望みならちと伝授しましょう」

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): He seemed highly elated.
坊っちゃん: とすこぶる得意である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Not for me!
坊っちゃん: だれがご伝授をうけるものか。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I take it this way that generally those who are fond of fishing or shooting have cruel hearts.
坊っちゃん: 一体釣や猟（りょう）をする連中はみんな不人情な人間ばかりだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Otherwise, there is no reason why they could derive pleasure in murdering innocent creatures.
坊っちゃん: 不人情でなくって、殺生（せっしょう）をして喜ぶ訳がない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Surely, fish and birds would prefer living to getting killed.
坊っちゃん: 魚だって、鳥だって殺されるより生きてる方が楽に極（き）まってる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Except those who make fishing or shooting their calling, it is nonsense for those who are well off to say that they cannot sleep well unless they seek the lives of fish or birds.
坊っちゃん: 釣や猟をしなくっちゃ活計（かっけい）がたたないなら格別だが、何不足なく暮（くら）している上に、生き物を殺さなくっちゃ寝られないなんて贅沢（ぜいたく）な話だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): This was the way I looked at the question, but as he was a B. A. and would have a better command of language when it came to talking, I kept mum, knowing he would beat me in argument.
坊っちゃん: こう思ったが向（むこ）うは文学士だけに口が達者だから、議論じゃ叶（かな）わないと思って、だまってた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Red Shirt mistook my silence for my surrender, and began to induce me to join him right away, saying he would show me some fish
坊っちゃん: すると先生このおれを降参させたと疳違（かんちが）いして、早速伝授しましょう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): and I should come with him if I was not busy,
坊っちゃん: おひまなら、今日どうです、いっしょに行っちゃ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): because he and Mr. Yoshikawa were lonesome when alone.
坊っちゃん: 吉川（よしかわ）君と二人（ふたり）ぎりじゃ、淋（さむ）しいから、来たまえとしきりに勧める。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Mr. Yoshikawa is the teacher of drawing whom I had nicknamed Clown.
坊っちゃん: 吉川君というのは画学の教師で例の野だいこの事だ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I don't know what's in the mind of this Clown, but he was a constant visitor at the house of Red Shirt, and wherever he went, Clown was sure to be trailing after him.
坊っちゃん: この野だは、どういう了見（りょうけん）だか、赤シャツのうちへ朝夕出入（でいり）して、どこへでも随行（ずいこう）して行（ゆ）く。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): They appeared more like master and servant than two fellow teachers.
坊っちゃん: まるで同輩（どうはい）じゃない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): As Clown used to follow Red Shirt like a shadow, it would be natural to see them go off together now, but when those two alone would have been well off, why should they invite me,--this brusque, unaesthetic fellow,--was hard to understand.
坊っちゃん: 赤シャツの行く所なら、野だは必ず行くに極（きま）っているんだから、今さら驚（おど）ろきもしないが、二人で行けば済むところを、なんで無愛想（ぶあいそ）のおれへ口を掛（か）けたんだろう。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Probably, vain of his fishing ability, he desired to show his skill, but he aimed at the wrong mark, if that was his intention, as nothing of the kind would touch me.
坊っちゃん: 大方高慢（こうまん）ちきな釣道楽で、自分の釣るところをおれに見せびらかすつもりかなんかで誘（さそ）ったに違いない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I would not be chagrined if he fishes out two or three tunnies.
坊っちゃん: 鮪（まぐろ）の二匹や三匹釣ったって、びくともするもんか。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I am a man myself and poor though I may be in the art, I would hook something if I dropped a line.
坊っちゃん: おれだって人間だ、いくら下手（へた）だって糸さえ卸（おろ）しゃ、何かかかるだろう、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): If I declined his invitation, Red Shirt would suspect that I refused not because of my lack of interest in the game but because of my want of skill of fishing.
坊っちゃん: ここでおれが行かないと、赤シャツの事だから、下手だから行かないんだ、嫌（きら）いだから行かないんじゃないと邪推（じゃすい）するに相違（そうい）ない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I weighed the matter thus, and accepted his invitation.
坊っちゃん: おれはこう考えたから、行きましょうと答えた。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): After the school, I returned home and got ready, and having joined Red Shirt and Clown at the station, we three started to the shore.
坊っちゃん: それから、学校をしまって、一応うちへ帰って、支度（したく）を整えて、停車場で赤シャツと野だを待ち合せて浜（はま）へ行った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): There was only one boatman to row;
坊っちゃん: 船頭は一人（ひとり）で、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): the boat was long and narrow, a kind we do not have in Tokyo.
坊っちゃん: 船（ふね）は細長い東京辺では見た事もない恰好（かっこう）である。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I looked for fishing rods but could find none.
坊っちゃん: さっきから船中見渡（みわた）すが釣竿（つりざお）が一本も見えない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
How can we fish without rods?	釣竿なしで釣が出来るものか、
How are we going to manage it?
坊っちゃん: どうする了見だろうと、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I asked Clown and he told me with the air of a professional fisherman that no rods were needed in the deep-sea fishing, but only lines.
坊っちゃん: 野だに聞くと、沖釣（おきづり）には竿は用いません、糸だけでげすと顋を撫（な）でて黒人（くろうと）じみた事を云った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I had better not asked him if I was to be talked down in this way.
坊っちゃん: こう遣（や）り込（こ）められるくらいならだまっていればよかった。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The boatman was rowing very slowly, but his skill was something wonderful.
坊っちゃん: 船頭はゆっくりゆっくり漕（こ）いでいるが熟練は恐（おそろ）しいもので、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): We had already come far out to sea, and on turning back, saw the shore minimized, fading in far distance.
坊っちゃん: 見返（みか）えると、浜が小さく見えるくらいもう出ている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): The five-storied pagoda of Tosho Temple appeared above the surrounding woods like a needle-point.
坊っちゃん: 高柏寺（こうはくじ）の五重の塔（とう）が森の上へ抜（ぬ）け出して針のように尖（とん）がってる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Yonder stood Aoshima (Blue Island).
坊っちゃん: 向側（むこうがわ）を見ると青嶋（あおしま）が浮いている。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Nobody was living on this island
坊っちゃん: これは人の住まない島だそうだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): which a closer view showed to be covered with stones and pine trees.
坊っちゃん: よく見ると石と松（まつ）ばかりだ。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): No wonder no one could live there.
坊っちゃん: なるほど石と松ばかりじゃ住めっこない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Red Shirt was intently surveying about and praising the general view as fine.
坊っちゃん: 赤シャツは、しきりに眺望（ちょうぼう）していい景色だと云ってる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Clown also termed it "an absolutely fine view."
坊っちゃん: 野だは絶景でげすと云ってる。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I don't know whether it is so fine as to be absolute, but there was no doubt as to the exhilarating air.
坊っちゃん: 絶景だか何だか知らないが、いい心持ちには相違ない。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I realized it as the best tonic to be thus blown by the fresh sea breeze upon a wide expanse of water.
坊っちゃん: ひろびろとした海の上で、潮風に吹（ふ）かれるのは薬だと思った。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): I felt hungry.
坊っちゃん: いやに腹が減る。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
Look at that pine;	「あの松を見たまえ、
its trunk is straight and spreads its top branches like an umbrella.	幹が真直（まっすぐ）で、上が傘（かさ）のように開いて
Isn't it a Turnersque picture?
坊っちゃん: ターナーの画にありそうだね」

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): said Red Shirt.
坊っちゃん: と赤シャツが野だに云うと、

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): Yes, just like Turner's,
坊っちゃん: 野だは

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): responded Clown,
坊っちゃん: 「全くターナーですね。

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING):
Isn't the way it curves just elegant?	どうもあの曲り具合ったらありませんね。
Exactly the touch of Turner,
坊っちゃん: ターナーそっくりですよ」

BOTCHAN (MASTER DARLING): he added with some show of pride.
坊っちゃん: と心得顔である。
